dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vast mansion is coming to life. Maids pull dustsheets off furniture; servants open shutters. Sunshine spills into the great rooms of Netherfield. outside, a glimpse of rolling parkland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "It is a truth universally acknowledged... Its a whirlwind of activity. Servants bustle around, sweeping and polishing, readying the house for its new occupants. The shutters of a room are opened onto the imposing gardens. A coach pulls up and, through the window, we see a young man get out. "that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife" A white sheet is pulled from a spinet and obscures our vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth Bennet, 20, good humoured, attractive, clearly nobody's fool, walks through a field of tall meadow grass. She is reading a novel entitled 'First Impressions'. She approaches Longbourn, a fairly run down 17th Century house with a small moat around it. Elizabeth jumps up onto a wall and crosses the moat by walking a wooden plank duck board, a reckless trick learnt in early childhood. She walks passed the back of the house where, through an open window to the library, we see her mother and father, Mr and Mrs Bennet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Mr Bennet, have you heard that Netherfield Park is let at last? We follow Elizabeth into the house, but still overhear her parents' conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you not want to know who has taken it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you wish to tell me, I doubt I have any choice in the matter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Elizabeth walks through the hallway, we hear the sound of piano scales plodding through the afternoon. She walks down the entrance hall past the room where Mary, 18, the bluestocking of the family, is practising, and finds Kitty, 16, the second youngest, and Lydia, 15, the precocious baby of the family, are listening at the door to the library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you heard? A Mr Bingley, a young man from the North of England, has come down on Monday in a chaise and four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With five thousand a year! Jane, (the eldest, most beautiful and most charmingly naive of the girls), joins them at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodness!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and he's single to be sure! INT. LIBRARY - LONGBOURN - CONTINUOUS. Mr Bennet is trying to ignore Mrs Bennet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a fine thing for our girls!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bow can it affect them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Mr Bennet, how can you be so tiresome! You know that he must marry one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so that is his design in settling here? Mr Bennet takes a book from his table and walks out of the library into the corridor where the girls are gathered, Mrs Bennet following. 4 INT. CORRIDOR - LONGBOURN - THE SAME. Mr Bennet walks through the girls to the drawing room pursued by Mrs Bennet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - So you must go and visit him at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bennet walks to the bookshelf to replace the book he is carrying. Mary is there practising the piano. The girls come in to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Papa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no need, for I already have. The piano stops. A frozen silence. They all stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў How can you tease me, Mr Bennet. You have no compassion for my poor nerves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mistake me, my dear. I have a high respect for them; they are my constant companions these twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he amiable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he handsome?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sure to be handsome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With five thousand a year, it would not matter if he had a big pink face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will give my hearty consent to his marrying whichever of the girls he chooses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So will he come to the ball tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe so. Lydia and Kitty shriek with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to have your spotted muslin, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - if you do, I'll lend you my green slippers. Mr Bennet winks at Elizabeth and turns to Mary, a serious, somewhat pedantic young woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you say, Mary? Are you not excited by the prospect of a ball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Society has claims on us all, Papa. As long as I have my mornings to myself, I consider an interval of recreation and ГўВЂВў amusement as quite desirable. Elizabeth laughs. 6 INT. ASSEMBLY ROOMS -- MERYTON VILLAGE - NIGHT. The local subscription dance is in full swing. It's a rough-and-ready, though enthusiastic affair...yeoman farmers, small-time squires with their ruddy-cheeked daughters. Lydia and Kitty, with their mother, are fussing over their clothes - straightening their dresses, tidying their hair and so on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fussing over her dress) I literally can't breathe its so tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My toes hurt. Elizabeth and Jane are a little apart from their family. Jane looks breathtaking. 0
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Well, if every man in this room does not end the evening completely in love with you then I am no judge of beauty. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or men. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they are far too easy to judge. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are not all bad. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humourless poppycocks, in my limited experience. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of these days, Lizzie, someone will catch your eye and then you'll have to watch your tongue. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And eat my hat. She stops speaking. And stares. A dazzling group enters the room: George Bingley, 25, a good hearted soul but ГўВЂВў prone to bumbling embarrassment when his enthusias the better of him, his sister Caroline, 23, a victim of every latest fashion, counting herself superior to most company she encounters, and finally, Mr Fitzwilliam Darcy, 27, dashing, brooding with an introversion which could be misconstrued as hauteur. They are dressed in the highest fashion. Darcy surveys the hall. He catches Elizabeth's eye. She stares, with a kind of surprised shock. Jane notices and looks at Darcy. He turns away. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luckily, you are not wearing a hat. A hush falls as the local people turn to stare. The newcomers - creatures from another world - make quite a stir. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline Bingley, standing next to Darcy, gazes at the somewhat provincial gathering with distaste. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are a long way from Grosvenor Square, are we not, Mr Darcy? He does indeed look superior to the assembled company. On the dance floor a young couple, staring at the newcomers, trip over each other, stumble and burst out laughing.
Mr Bingley spots Jane Bennet. For a moment he forgets himself and openly looks at her. MR BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find it very charming. CAROLINE BINGLEY (TO DARCY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother is so easily pleased, is he not? Darcy does not answer. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth has found her great friend Charlotte Lucas - an intelligent, sensible woman in her late twenties. They spy through the crowd. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So which of the painted peacocks is our Mr Bingley? CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is on the right, and on the left is his sister. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the person with the disagreeable expression? CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is his good friend, Mr Darcy. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor soul. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary, he has ten thousand a year and owns half of Derbyshire. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir William Lucas, 53 a hale but unsophisticated member of the self-made gentry, takes it upon himself to introduce Mr Bingley and Mr Darcy to his daughter Charlotte and the Bennet family. SIR WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mr Bingley) My eldest daughter you know, Mrs Bennet ...miss Jane Bennet, Elizabeth and Miss Mary Bennet. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a pleasure. I have two others but 40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: they are already dancing.
MR BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delighted to make your acquaintance. Г‚ВЂВў SIR WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And may I introduce Mr Darcy. (SIGNIFICANT LOOK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- of Pemberley, in Derbyshire! A stiff bow from Darcy, Elizabeth smiles, Darcy does not. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Elizabeth is standing in a small group with Jane, Bingley, Miss Bingley and Darcy. Bingley can't keep his eyes off Jane, but is frightfully at a loss in disguising his instant ardour. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like it here in Hertfordshire, Mr Bingley? MR BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling at Jane shyly) Very much. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The library at Netherfield, I've heard, is one of the finest in the country. Г‚ВЂВў MR BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it fills me with guilt. He looks at Jane a little blush starts around his collar. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a good reader, you see. I like being out of doors. I mean, I can read, of COURSE -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His sister steps in. as the blush threatens to engulf his ears. MISS BINGLEY (TO DARCY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your library at Pemberly, Mr Darcy, is astonishingly good. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. It is the work of many generations. MISS BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then you have added so much to it yourself. 0
JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I read more, but there always seems so many other things to do. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what I meant. He beams at Jane. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr and Mrs Bennet stand a little apart from Elizabeth and the other young people. Lydia and Kitty bound up to them in a state of high excitement. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama! The regiment is arriving next week! KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And will be here for the whole winter! Mrs Forster told us! LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to be stationed in the village! CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bingley'turns to Jane. MR BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have the honour? They leave, to dance. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you dance Mr Darcy? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if I can help it. Elizabeth, Darcy and Miss Bingley stand in silence as they over hear the following... CUT TO: LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: officers! Lots of officers! KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How will we meet them? LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's easy. You just walk up and down in front of them and drop something. Lydia pantomimes the actions for Kitty.
LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў They pick it up. You say 'oh thank you sir' and blush prettily and then you're introduced! MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have long suspected that we have two of the silliest girls in the county. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Mr Bennet! I remember the time when I liked a red coat myself, and if a smart young colonel with six thousand a year should want one of my girls I shall not say nay to him. Mr Darcy overhears this. Profoundly embarrassed, Lizzie moves away. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dance floor. Mr Bingley is dancing with Jane. His ears blushing with thrilled embarrassment. Mrs Bennet, with a group of other mothers, watches the young couple with rather too obvious satisfaction. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 That dress becomes her, does it not. 7 ГўВЂВў Though of course my Jane needs little help from couturiers. Elizabeth wanders through the throng. She looks at Bingley and Jane ending the dance - she is coy and demure, he clearly smitten - CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darcy is joined by Bingley exhilarated by the dance. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come Darcy, I must have you dance. I hate to see you standing by yourself in this stupid manner. MR DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) You know how I detest it. MR BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upon my word, I've never seen so many pretty girls in my life. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are dancing with the only handsome girl in the room. Г‚ВЂВў
BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, she is the most beautiful creature I ever beheld, but her sister Elizabeth is very agreeable. They have stopped at the edge of the dance floor and have not seen Elizabeth and charlotte who are standing close behind them. Elizabeth smirks as she overhears their conversation. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly tolerable, I dare say, but not handsome enough to tempt me. Elizabeth's smile drops. DARCY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had better return to your partner and enjoy her smiles, for you are wasting your time with me. Bingley goes off. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Charlotte, who have overheard Darcy and Bingley's exchange. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignore him, Lizzie, he is such a disagreeable man it would be a misfortune to be liked by him. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I would not dance with him for half of Derbyshire. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Bingley politely dancing with Charlotte. As he does so, he catches sight of Jane dancing with somebody else. A look of pure longing, but he cannot dance every dance with her. Lizzie too is dancing and clocks this. Lydia and Kitty are exuberantly dancing too, laughing and chatting. Darcy stands watching, a look of infinitely superior boredom on his fine features. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingley is standing with Jane, Elizabeth, Mrs Bennet and Darcy. BINGLEY (TO LIZZIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friend Miss Lucas is a most amusing young woman.
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Yes! I adore her. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a pity she is not more handsome. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama! MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Lizzie will never admit she is plain. (TO BINGLEY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it's my Jane who's considered the beauty of the county. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mama, please! MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she was only fifteen there was a gentleman so much in love with her that I was sure he would make her an offer. However, he did write her some very pretty verses. ELIZABETH (IMPATIENTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so ended their affection. I wonder ГўВЂВў who first discovered the power of poetry in driving away love? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought that poetry was the food of love. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of a fine, stout love it may. Everything nourishes what is strong already. But if it is only a thin, slight sort of inclination, I'm convinced that one good sonnet will starve it away entirely. Darcy looks at Elizabeth with surprise. A glimmering of interest. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you recommend, to encourage affection? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dancing, of course. Even if ones partner is barely tolerable. She gives him a dazzling smile. Darcy looks startled. He has no idea she heard him. He blushes. Г‚ВЂВў CUT TO:
Elizabeth is dancing happily in a round, Jane and Bingley ГўВЂВў are also in the same dance. At the edge of the dan floor Darcy is watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Jane are both tucked up in the same bed, but are too excited to sleep. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bingley is just what a young man ought to be. Sensible, good humoured - ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (completing the list) Handsome, conveniently rich - JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know perfectly well I do not believe marriage should be driven by thoughts of money. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree entirely, only the deepest love will persuade me into matrimony, which is why I will end up an old maid. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really believe he liked me, Lizzie? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, he danced with you most of the night. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was flattered, I must admit. I did not expect such a compliment. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is one great difference between us. Compliments always take you by surprise. Well, Mr Bingley is certainly very amiable, and I give you leave to like him. You've liked many a stupider person. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a great deal too apt to like people in general, you know. All the world is good and agreeable in your eyes. 0
Г‚ВЂВў JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not his friend. I still cannot believe what he said about you. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy? I could more easily forgive his vanity had he not wounded mine. But no matter. I doubt we shall ever speak again. She blows out the candle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Bennet presides over breakfast with an endless description of the ball. Mary is doing some needle work, whilst Lydia, Kitty and Jane blearily eat. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then he danced the third with Miss Lucas. Poor thing, it is a shame she is not more handsome. The fourth with a Miss King of little standing. And the fifth again with Jane. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў If he'd had any compassion for me he would have sprained his ankle in the first dance. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr Bennet! Anybody would think the girls looked forward to a grand inheritance. Elizabeth rolls her eyes at Mr Bennet, they've heard this speech many times before. MR BENNET (NOT LISTENING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty, be so kind as to pass the butter. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you well know, Mr Bennet, when you die, which may in fact be very soon, our girls will be left without a roof over their head nor a penny to their name. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Mother, please! It's ten in the morning. Mrs Hill enters the room and interrupts Mrs Bennet's ГўВЂВў babbling.
MRS HILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў A letter addressed to Miss Bennet, Ma'arn. From Netherfield Hall. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Praise the Lord! We are saved. Mrs Hill gives the letter to Jane.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Make haste, Jane, make haste. 0 happy day! JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is from Miss Bingley. Mrs Bennet is stopped in her tracks. JANE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has invited me to dine with her. (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her brother will be dining out. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is most unfortunate. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think he was so good looking anyway. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I take the carriage? MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not my dear, you will go to Netherfield on horse back. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horseback?! Mrs Bennet leaves with a secret smile on her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane rides through the countryside, A distant rumble of thunder. She looks up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open book. Plop plop! Raindrops fall on it. Drawing back, we see Lizzie walking through a field, reading. She looks up to the sky... 0

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Bennet stands at the kitchen door. A boy is delivering meat. It starts to rain. She puts out her hand, to check. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, satisfied) Ah, good... The housekeeper, Mrs Hill, who is with her, looks bemused at her mistress's reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A louder rumble of thunder. A washerwoman hastily pulls clothes from a line...it's bucketing down heavily now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the local.village people run for cover; shopkeepers cover up their wares... ГўВЂВў 14 EXT. LONGBOURN - DAY. 14 Mr and Mrs Bennet look out at the pouring rain. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. Now she will have to stay the night. Exactly as I predicted. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good grief, woman. Your skills in the art of match-making are without question. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though I don't think, mama, you can reasonably take credit for making it rain. Let's hope she hasn't caught her death before she gets there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A footman opens the great doors to find Jane standing there soaked. she sneezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Elizabeth reads a letter.
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў "And my kind friends will not hear of me returning home until I am better -- but do not be alarmed excepting a sore throat, a. fever, and a headache there is nothing wrong with me." This is ridiculous. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my dear, if your daughter does die it will be a comfort to know it was all in pursuit of Mr Bingley. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People do not die of colds. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though she might well perish with the shame of having such a mother. Mr Bennet laughs. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going to Netherfield at once. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense, the horse is with Jane. And the girls took the carriage to town. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I will walk there. We should not leave Jane alone in her condition. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk! You will not be fit to be seen by the time you get there. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the devil not. We could have them all laid up at Netherfield Hall. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will be fit for Jane which is all I care about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth strides across vast muddy fields, slipping as she goes. Netherfield is in view on the horizon. She stops to take it in, then carries on down an even more muddy track. 18 INT. NETHERFIELD -- BREAKFAST ROOM - DAY. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the large grand dining room Caroline Bingley and Darcy are eating breakfast.
Its very formal, in fact frigid, compared to the volatile Bennet household. Darcy is reading the ГўВЂВў newspaper; Caroline Bingley is reading a letter. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puts down the letter) Apparently, Lady Bathurst is redecorating her ballroom in the French style. A little unpatriotic, don't you think? Mr Darcy is about to answer when the door opens. A footman appears, his face rigid with disapproval. FOOTMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Elizabeth Bennet. Lizzie comes in, her face flushed, her skirt covered in mud. She looks ravishing. Darcy stares at her, then quickly rises to his feet. Caroline Bingley, astonished, looks her up and down. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord, Miss Bennet. Have you walked here? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry. How is my sister? DARCY (MORE KINDLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's upstairs. (TO FOOTMAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show Miss Bennet the way, Alfred. Lizzie leaves. A beat. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodness, did you see her petticoat? Six inches deep in mud! No response. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And her hair, so blowsy and untidy! DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think her concern for her sister does her credit. A little pause, Caroline recovers. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, its shocking to have a bad cold. I dislike excessively being ill myself. 0
ГўВЂВў 19 INT. NETHERFIELD LANDING - DAY. I Elizabeth is taken upstairs. Bingley, looking tense, waits outside her sister's room. His face lights up when he sees her. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Elizabeth! Oh I'm so glad to see you A doctor comes out of Jane's room.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH AND BINGLEY
dialogues.text: (TOGETHER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is she? DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A violent cold, but we shall get the better of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth goes into the bedroom where Jane lies in bed, feverish and ill. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane! Jane's face lights up. Elizabeth kisses her. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie! Oh, your face is so cold. They're being so kind to me, I feel such a terrible imposition. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I don't know who is more pleased at your being here, Mama or Mr Bingley. Bingley comes in having attended to the doctor. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for tending to my sister so diligently, it seems she is in better comfort here than she would be at home. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a pleasure, I mean not to see her so sick, of course, that's terrible. I will have a room made up for you. You must be our guest here until Jane recovers. Г‚ВЂВў
Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darcy is quietly reading as Bingley paces about anxiously. Caroline berates him from the sofa. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay!? She is a perfectly sweet girl but save being an excellent walker, there is very little to recommend her. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought she showed remarkable spirit coming all this way. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eldest Miss Bennet, as you know, I hold in excessive regard and I wish her well settled. Though I do fear with her families low connections there is little chance of it. Their uncle is in trade, you know, in Cheapside. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they had uncles enough to fill all Cheapside it would not make them one jot less agreeable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bennet is overseeing the gardener who is pruning the hedge. Mrs Bennet bustles up. She looks very pleased with herself. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my dear, its all going according to plan. He's half in love with her already! MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a touch disingenuously) Who, my sweetest? MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bingley! And he doesn't mind that she hasn't a penny, for he has enough for the two of them. Suddenly a distant trumpet sounds, dogs bark. The militia are arriving. Lydia and Kitty rush past. They are dressed up to the nines to greet the officers. Mrs Bennet's face lights up. ГўВЂВў MRS BENNET Wait for me!
And she's gone. Mr Bennet gazes at their departing ГўВЂВў figures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Bennet and her two daughters rush down the street into the village. Dogs bark, children run alongside as a regiment of soldiers march through the street. Geese scatter; shopkeepers stand in their doorways. The two Bennet girls simper at the handsome young soldiers. Mrs Bennet, flushed and excited, runs panting behind them. Lydia deliberately drops her hankerchief. One of the soldiers stands on it. She is appalled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is reading a book. Darcy is writing a letter. Bingley is sat nervously. Caroline, obviously bored, wanders the room looking for distraction. She looks over Darcy's shoulder. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You write uncommonly fast, Mr Darcy. MR DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) ГўВЂВў You are mistaken. I write rather slowly. Caroline Bingley lingers, annoyingly. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many letters you must have occasion to write, Mr Darcy. Letters of business too. How odious I should think them! DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is fortunate, then, that they fall to my lot instead of yours. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please tell your sister that I long to see her. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have already told her once, by your desire. Lizzie looks across from her book. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do dote on her, I was quite in raptures at her beautiful little design for a table. Г‚ВЂВў
DARCY Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you will give me leave to defer your raptures till I write again. At present I have not enough room to do them justice. Mr Bingley now pacing anxiously around the room. MR BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its amazing, how young ladies have the patience to be so accomplished. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Charles? MR BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all paint tables, and embroider cushions and play the piano. I never heard of a young lady, but people say she is accomplished. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The word is indeed applied too liberally. I cannot boast of knowing more than half a dozen women, in all my acquaintance, that are truely accomplished. ГўВЂВў CAROLINE BINGLEY Nor I, to be sure! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodness! You must comprehend a great deal in the idea. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. She must have a thorough knowledge of music, singing, drawing, dancing and the modern languages, to deserve the word. And something in her air and manner of walking. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And of course she must improve her mind by extensive reading. Elizabeth closes her book. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i am no longer surprised at your knowing only six accomplished women. I rather wonder now at your knowing any. Г‚ВЂВў DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you so severe on your own sex?
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў I never saw such a woman. She would certainly be a fearsome thing to behold. Pause. Darcy goes back to his letter. Caroline Bingley picks up a book. Pauses. Puts it down. she walks over to LIZZIE_ CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bennet, let us take a turn about the room. Lizzie, surprised, gets up. Caroline Bingley links her arm and they start walking up and down.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE BINGLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's refreshing, is it not, after sitting so long in one attitude? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's a small kind of accomplishment, I suppose. Darcy meets Lizzie's eye, briefly. He goes back to his letter-writing. More walking up and down. Caroline Bingley turns to Darcy. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy, will you join us? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) You can only have two motives, Miss Bingley, and I would interfere with either. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lizzie, archly) What can he mean? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our surest way of disappointing him will be to ask nothing about it. CAROLINE BINGLEY (TO DARCY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please tell us! DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either you are in each other's confidence and have secret affairs to discuss, or you are conscious that your figures appear to the greatest advantage by walking. If the first, I should get in your way. If the second, I can admire you ГўВЂВў much better from here.
ГўВЂВў CAROLINE BINGLEY Oh, shocking! How shall we punish him for such a speech? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could always tease him. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, Mr Darcy is not to be laughed at! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you too proud, Mr Darcy? And would you consider that a fault? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I couldn't say. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For we're trying to find a fault in you. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's that I find it hard to forgive the follies and vices of others, or their offences against myself. My good opinion, once lost, is lost forever. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Oh dear, I cannot tease you about that. What a shame, for I dearly love to laugh. CAROLINE BINGLEY (SMALL SMILE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A family trait I think. Elizabeth smiles, sweetly. Miss Bingley glances at Darcy.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Elizabeth wakes up next to Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darcy gallops through the countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darcy, exhausted, rides into the stable yard. In the corner is a trough and pump. He strides up to the pump, puts his head under it and douses himself with cold water. 0

ГўВЂВў 28 INT/EXT. BEDROOM/STABLE YARD -- NETHERFIELD - T From a window Elizabeth looks out at Darcy. Darcy looks up and for a second catches Elizabeth looking down at him. She turns from the window. Jane is waking up. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, do you think you might feel well enough to leave today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors open. The Butler as before: BUTLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Mrs Bennet, a Miss Bennet, a Miss Bennet and a Miss Bennet, sir. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we to receive every Bennet in the country? Mrs Bennet, Lydia, Mary and Kitty are introduced to Caroline, Bingley and Darcy. Elizabeth holds her breath as her mother launches into untold gaucheries. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What an excellent room you have sir. Such expensive furnishings. I hope you intend to stay here, Mr Bingley. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely I find the country very diverting. Don't you agree, Darcy? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find it perfectly adequate even if society is a little less varied than in town. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I assure you there is quite as much going on in the country as there is in the town. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed Mania, I think Mr Darcy merely meant there were not such a variety of people to be met in the country as there are in town, which you must acknowledge to be true. Г‚ВЂВў
ГўВЂВў MRS BENNET Nonsense, we dine with four and twenty families. Sir William Lucas for instance is a very agreeable man. So very genteel and easy. Elizabeth cringes. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bingley, is it true that you have promised to hold a ball here at Netherfield? BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be an excellent way to meet new friends. You could invite the militia. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh do hold a ball. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to stop Bingley being BAMBOOZLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty... BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When your sister has recovered you shall name the day. MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think a Ball is a perfectly irrational way to gain new acquaintance. It would be better if conversation instead of dancing were the order of the day. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed much more rational but rather less like a ball. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mary. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mrs Bennet) Please let me show you to Jane, you will find her quite recovered. CUT TO: 0

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bennet's carriage awaits. The Bingley's are gathered to see the Bennet's off. Jane is radiant - in the peak of health. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Bingley's) Really, I don't know how to thank you. Bingley beams bashfully. He can't take his eyes off her. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, you're welcome anytime you feel the least bit poorly. ELIZABETH (TO CAROLINE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for such stimulating company. It has been most instructive. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. The pleasure is all mine. Elizabeth looks at Darcy, who does not say anything. She gets in the carriage. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bennet. They share a look as Elizabeth joins the rest of the Bennets in the carriage. The driver takes off. Bingley waves enthusiastically to Jane. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family are all squeezed in rather too tightly. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a high and mighty man that Mr Darcy is, quite eaten up with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bennet's carriage is stopped in its tracks by the Militia who are marching en masse through town.

ГўВЂВў 33 INT. CARRIAGE - MERYTON - DAY. 33 Lydia cannot believe her eyes as row after row of soldiers pass by the carriage with not a few of the men looking in at the Bennet girls with some interest. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it, there must be a thousand of them. Leading the one troupe of Militia is Wickham a very handsome blonde officer, Lydia spots him and swoons. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the coachman) Please, drive on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Bennet girls come into the house, Lydia eulogizing the Militia, they meet Mr Bennet. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope, my dear, that you have ordered a good dinner today, because I have reason to expect an addition to our family Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: party. Mr Bennet holds up the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collins, late twenties, an overweening sychophant, nervous and unctuous in equal measure. He sits in his black garb, hunched uncomfortably as he comes through town.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Dear sir, the disagreement subsisting between yourself and my late father over the entail to me of the Longbourn estate, has long been a subject of much torment which I have frequently wished to heal. Having received ordination this Easter and being so fortunately distinguished by the patronage of the Right Honorable Lady Catherine de Bourgh..." Collins' voice fades out as his carriage wipes through frame revealing Elizabeth and Charlotte on their way to the butchers. 0
LIZZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў His name is Mr Collins. He's the dreaded cousin. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's to inherit? LIZZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. Everything, apparently. He may leave us our stays, but even my piano stool belongs to Mr Collins. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? LIZZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can turn us out of the house as soon as he pleases. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why? LIZZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because the estate is entailed to him and not to us poor females. A cart passes, crammed with sheep going to slaughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Collins is ushered in by the manservant, Perkins. He looks around his future home with interest. Mr and Mrs Bennet greet him. MR COLLINS (DEEP BOW )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Collins, at your service. (LOOKS AROUND)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a charming house! So convenient for the local village. (looks at the furniture) And some very fine pieces, if I'm not mistaken. A beat. This is hardly tactful. MRS BENNET (COLDLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are. Jane, Lizzie and Mary enter. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, these are your daughters, are they not?
MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have some more somewhere. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must congratulate you. I have heard much of their beauty, but in this instance fame has fallen short of the truth. A very low bow. The girls are somewhat taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bennets and Collins are seated formally for supper. Mr Collins is served some food. COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a superbly featured room and what excellent boiled potatoes. It is many years since I had such an exemplary vegetable. To which of my fair cousins should I compliment the excellence of the cooking? MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Collins, we are perfectly able to keep a cook. Г‚ВЂВў COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. I am very pleased the estate affords such a living. I am honoured to have, as my patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourg, you have heard of her, I presume? Mrs Bennet shakes her head. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My small rectory abuts her estate, Rosings Park, and she often condescends to drive by my humble abode in her little phaeton and ponies. A pause. Lizzie catches her father's eye. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does she have any family? MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One daughter, the heiress of Rosings and very extensive property. I have often observed to Lady Catherine, that her daughter seemed born to be a duchess for she has all the superior graces of ГўВЂВў elevated rank. (LITTLE COUGH) (MORE)
MR COLLINS (cont'd) .These are the kind of little delicate compliments that are always acceptable to 1ГЇВїВЅ1 ladies, and which I conceive myself particularly bound to pay. MR BENNET (GRAVELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How happy for you, Mr Collins, to possess the talent for flattering with delicacy. Mr Collins nods with satisfaction. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the moment or are they the result of previous study? Jane kicks Elizabeth under the table. Elizabeth tries not to laugh at Mr Collins' answer. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arise chiefly from what is passing at the time, and though I sometimes amuse myself with arranging such little elegant compliments, I always wish to give them as unstudied an air as possible. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, no one would suspect your manners to be practised. The girls look at one another. COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After dinner I thought I might read to you all an hour or two. I have with me Fordyce's sermons which speak eloquently on this point. (TO JANE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know Fordyce's sermons Miss Bennet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later; we can see the girls and Mr Bennet gathered by the fire through the doorway. Mr Collins leaves the room and takes Mrs Bennet aside to a very discrete conference, out of hearing of anyone else. COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Bennet. You do know I have been bestowed by the good grace of Lady Catherine de Bough a parsonage of no mean size. ГўВЂВў MRS BENNET I have become aware of the fact.
COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Well, it.is my avowed hope that soon I may find a mistress for it, and I have to inform you that the eldest Miss Bennet has captured my special attention. Collins looks lasciviously into the room. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Collins, unfortunately it is incumbent on me to hint that the eldest Miss Bennet is - very soon to be engaged. COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Engaged! MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Miss Elizabeth next to her in both age and beauty would make anyone an excellent partner. Do not you agree, Mr Collins? Mr Collins looks through the doorway at Elizabeth COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. Indeed. A very agreeable alternative. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Jane are walking towards the house when, across the moat, they see Mr Collins come out of the house and advance towards them. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no! Mx Collins spots them and darts through a door in the garden wall and hurries towards the bridge to meet them. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick! This way! She pulls Jane across the duck board spanning the moat, through the house and out the front. Mr Collins doubles back and follows them into the house. The girls are no-where to be seen. He looks around, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Elizabeth and Jane arrive in the village. Jane, fo the dutiful daughter, looks uneasy- Elizabeth is flushed and reckless. She looks behind them-
ELIZABETH (LAUGHS) Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've lost him. They slow down to a walk. And then stop. outside the milliner's shop the incorrigible Lydia and Kitty are chatting to Wickham, the dashing young officer we spotted earlier. He is utterly gorgeous - slim, handsome, tousled hair. The perfect romantic hero. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty? Lydia! She and Jane join them. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just happened to be looking for some ribbon, didn't we, Kitty? (KITTY NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we met Mr Wickham. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picked up Lydia's gloves! LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a lieutenant! Wickham bows. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm enchanted. Shall we all look at some ribbons together? LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come into the shop. The others go towards the counter. Wickham hangs back, and smiles a complicit, witty smile at Elizabeth. She colours. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though I must warn you, I have very poor taste. ELIZABETH (SMILES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a man truly confident of himself would admit that. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's true. My rooms in town, decorated, I thought, in the height of ГўВЂВў fashion, have reduced grown men to tears of mirth.
ELIZABETH' Г‚ВЂВў (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why don't you change them? MR WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And deny people such pleasure? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't mind being laughed at? MR WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not particularly. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a somewhat sterile quality, is it not, to be aware of ones importance in the world. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially if, like me, one has none. Elizabeth looks at him with interest. A beat. The moment is broken by Lydia coming up. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie, please lend me some money! ELIZABETH Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already owe me a considerable sum, Liddy. MR WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow me to oblige. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Please - Mr Wickham! - Wickham gives Elizabeth a smile and moves away to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls emerge from the shop with Wickham. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too generous. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Fivepence halfpenny! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It all adds up. Г‚ВЂВў LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pay him back.
WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. I'll make sure of that. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh. Elizabeth is really rather taken with him. They walk down the street. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be stationed here all winter, Mr Wickham? WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends on what the French have in mind. Of course I look forward to action... (smiles at her) But on the other hand JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie - look! They stop. Jane's face lights up. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bingley ! It is indeed Bingley, riding towards them. He is accompanied by Darcy. ГўВЂВў Bingley jumps off his horse and hurries over to Ja open, friendly face is filled with delight. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was on my way to your house. LYDIA -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please Mr Bingley, when are you going to give a ball? JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia! BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just waiting until your sister was quite well.- LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is! Elizabeth pays no attention to the following conversation, instead she is looking at Darcy who, in turn, is staring at Wickham. They both obviously recognize each other and look very uncomfortable. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - when, then?
MR BINGLEY Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as they have made the white soup. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be sure to invite Mr Wickham. Darcy turns and rides off without a word. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia, you can't just say that - MR BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you excuse me ladies? Mr Wickham. Enjoy the day. Elizabeth looks at Wickham, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small cards party is underway. Three tables have been set up. Elizabeth, Wickham, Jane, Lydia, Kitty, Charlotte and Sir William and Lady Lucas are present. A small number of officers and other ladies are also present. We move around the tables. Kitty is sat with Sir William and Charlotte and Mary. Jane sits at a table with Mr Collins and Lady Lucas. Lizzie sits with Lydia and two other officers. Lydia flirts outrageously. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA.
dialogues.text: We have asked mama if we might have new dresses for the Netherfield ball. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, white, they must be white. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White is the only colour to be worn this season. SIR WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I believe. Mr Collins is at a table with Lady Lucas, he glances over at Elizabeth, as he talks. COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - of course, when you understand that Lady Catherine de Bourgh is its proprietor you will realise what an immense compliment that is. Lady Catherine spent eight hundred pounds on a chimney-piece alone. ГўВЂВў Wickham who has been talking to some of the other officers comes and sits beside Elizabeth, passing by Mr collins on the way.
WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside to Elizabeth) Your cousin is blessed with an uncommon capacity for charm. Elizabeth laughs and plays a hand. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be attending the Netherfield ball, Mr Wickham? WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope to. (TO ELIZABETH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has Mr Darcy been a guest a Netherfield? Elizabeth pounces on this reference to Mr Darcy and takes her chance. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a month. Are you acquainted with, Mr Darcy? WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, my fate has been very intimate with that gentleman. I have been connected with his family since infancy. Elizabeth is genuinely surprised, there is a pause while she is forced to play her hand. WICKHAM (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may well be surprised, Miss Bennet, especially given the cold manner of our intimacy this afternoon. Are you well acquainted with that gentleman? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As much as I could ever wish to be. I have spent four days in the same house as him, and I think him very disagreeable. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot pretend to be sorry. Elizabeth blushes. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But really I speak out of turn. Collins voice breaks the moment. COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Elizabeth, I was just saying to Sir William what appalling weather we've been having.
Elizabeth cannot believe her misfortune in Mr Collins, ГўВЂВў but she smiles politely. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I shall take a little air. She rises and walks through the room towards a balcony. As she passes the other tables we follow and witness snippets of their conversations. CHARLOTTE (TO MARY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems Mr Wickham has met with universal approval. Though Lizzie looks singularly pleased with him. MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the moment she has more suitors than sense. Charlotte looks over at Mr Collins. Elizabeth passes Sir William's side of the table. SIR WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now any one for a round of bridge? Elizabeth? ELIZABETH Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really I need to take some air. Mr Collins makes his way to join Elizabeth. SIR WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Collins? COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I am not so familiar with the game, Sir William. SIR WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolute nonsense. I insist that you join us. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mr Collins, I'd be happy if you'd PARTNER ME_

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collins resigns himself to his fate. Elizabeth smiles and slips out into the night air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth breathes in the cold night air. She senses someone join her. She looks round to see Wickham has followed her as she had hoped.
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў I hope your plans in favor of Meryton will not be affected by your difficult relations with the gentleman we were just speaking of. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no - it is not for me to be driven away. If he wishes to avoid seeing me, he must go not I. Pause. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must ask you Mr Wickham, what is the manner of your disapproval of Mr Darcy? WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really want to hear? Lizzie nods. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ruined me. She stares at him. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How so? WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father managed his estate. We grew up together, Darcy and I. His father treated me like a second son. Oh he was the kindest of men and bequeathed me the best living in his gift, for I had my heart set on joining the church. But when he died Darcy ignored his wishes and gave the living to another man. LIZZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did he do that? WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of jealousy, for his father loved me more than he loved him. LIZZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How cruel! Are you sure? WICKHAM (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And out of pride, for he considered me too lowly to be worth his consideration. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Lizzie gazes at him with horror and sympathy.

ГўВЂВў 45 INT. BEDROOMS - LONGBOURNE - THE SAME. 45 We pan through the bedrooms as the Bennet girls prepare for the Netherfield ball. Kitty is helping Lydia into her dress, they are both wearing white. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aggghh! KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathe in! We move to the quieter preparations of Jane and Elizabeth. This conversation has been going on for some time. JANE (HORRIFIED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - I still think there must have been a misunderstanding. LIZZIE (EXASPERATED LAUGH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jane, do you never think ill of anybody? JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0 How could Mr Darcy do such a thing? I will discover the truth from Mr Bingley at the ball this evening. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it is not true let Mr Darcy contradict it himself. But until he does, I hope never to encounter him. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor, unfortunate Mr Wickham. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary, he is twice the man Darcy is. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And lets hope for you a rather more willing dancer. Jane leaves Elizabeth, at the mirror, taking very particular care of her makeup. she smil6s to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў The great doors of Netherfield open to reveal the full swing. Compared to the somewhat clod-hopping Assembly, its a dazzling affair.

There are hundreds of guests. All the women, roughly two hundred, are dressed in white. The men are either in red ГўВЂВў officer uniform or dressed in black and white. The a number of rooms each occupied by a different activity, cards, buffet, women's closet. The final and grandest room is the ball room, a swirl of elegant dance. The Bennet's enter the first reception room, the girls, including Mrs Bennet, are all dressed in white. Mr Collins is slightly detained as people pass. Mr Bingley bounds up to Jane. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're here! I'm so pleased. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so am I. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Miss Elizabeth? Elizabeth is not paying attention, instead she is searching over Mr Bingleys' shoulder for a sight of Wickham. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you, looking for someone? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў No, no not at all. Admiring the splendor of the ball. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is lovely, Mr Bingley. Bingley and Jane move off leaving Elizabeth with Mrs Bennet and others. While Mrs Bennet talks we focus on Elizabeth searching the sea of red coats. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (refering to Jane and BINGLEY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dare say I have never met a more pleasant gentleman in all my years. Look how he dotes on her! Still Jane has always done what is best for her family. Elizabeth takes this opportunity to slip away into the next room. Elizabeth looks around but cannot see Mr Wickham. Suddenly she thinks she sees him, so starts to a r, move over. The man turns round, it is not Wickham bu someone else. Elizabeth walks nonchanantly into the next room, again looking for Mr Wickham. She cranes around trying to see ГўВЂВў him then she is suddenly surprised by Charlotte Lu
ELIZABETH Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen Mr Wickham. She shakes her head. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps he is in the ballroom. They both walk into the ball room. We pull back to reveal a sea of dancers. Wickham is nowhere to be seen. Jane appears and catches Elizabeths arm. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not here. Apparently otherwise detained. The disappointment is palpable on Elizabeth's face. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detained? Mr Collins arrives, breathless. He smiles eagerly at Elizabeth. COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are. Г‚ВЂВў ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Collins. What a pleasant surprise. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you will do me the honour, Miss Elizabeth? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I didn't think you danced, Mr Collins. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not consider it incompatible with the office of a clergyman to indulge in such an innocent diversion. Elizabeth tries to smile, politely.

dialogues.speaker: MR COLLINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In fact several people, her ladyship included, have complimented me on my lightness of foot. Elizabeth's face is a matey rictus. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў They dance, the style of which is not unlike Engli Country dancing.
COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў To be sure, dancing is of little consequence to me, but it does afford the opportunity to lavish'ones partner with delicate attentions which is my primary object of the evening. Elizabeth turns as part of the dance and for a moment she dances beside Jane. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently Your Mr Wickham has been called on some business to town, though my informer told me he would have been less inclined to be engaged had it not been for the presence at Netherfield of a certain gentleman. Jane indicates towards where Darcy stands watching them. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That gentleman barely warrants the name. The dance leads Elizabeth back to Mr Collins.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS
dialogues.text: It is my intention, if I may be so bold to remain close to you throughout the evening. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couples are preparing for the next dance. Elizabeth and Charlotte are standing to one side when Mr Darcy approaches. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have the next dance, Miss Elizabeth. Elizabeth is stunned. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may. Darcy walks away. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was I thinking? Have I no presence of mind?l CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dare say you will find him very agreeable, Lizzie. 0
Г‚ВЂВў ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heaven forbid! That would be the greatest misfortune of all - to find a man agreeable whom one is determined to hate! CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth dances face to face with Darcy. Neither can speak. They dance for a moment in silence. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do love a Sarabande. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. Most invigorating. They continue, for a moment, in silence. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is your turn to say something, Mr Darcy - I talked about the dance, now you ought to remark on the size of the room or the number of couples. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am perfectly happy to oblige, please advise me of what you would like most to ГўВЂВў hear. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That reply will do for the present. Perhaps by and bye I may observe that private balls are much pleasanter than public ones. But for now we may be silent. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you talk as a rule while dancing? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are each of an unsocial, taciturn disposition, unwilling to speak, unless we expect to say something that will - amaze the whole room, and be handed down to posterity with all the eclat of a proverb. So a little lubrication to avoid embarrassment might be advantageous. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see no striking resemblance of your own character in this, how near it is to mine I cannot say. (beat) Tell me do you and your sisters very often walk to Meryton? Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are suddenly parted by the choreography of the dance.

We stay with Elizabeth who is whisked round the floor by an elderly man who smiles at her toothlessly, Elizabeth ГўВЂВў looks back at Darcy who is dancing with Lydia. He at Elizabeth as he dances. Elizabeth smiles at her current partner in embarrassment. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very mild weather we've been having. DANCING PARTNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deaf as a post) Sorry. The dance spins again and she is back with Darcy. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we often walk to Meryton - it is a great opportunity to meet new people. In fact when you met us we had just had the pleasure of forming a new acquaintance. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will admit your Mr Wickham is blessed with such happy manners as may ensure his making friends - whether he is capable of retaining them is less certain. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has been so unlucky as to lose your friendship. I remember hearing you once say that your resentment once created was unappeasable. You are very cautious, I suppose, as to its being created? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. May I ask to what these questions tend. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To make out your character, Mr Darcy. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what have you discovered? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: very little. The dancefinishes. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear such different accounts of you as puzzle me exceedingly. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope to afford you more clarity in the ГўВЂВў future.
ГўВЂВў They bow to each other and Elizabeth moves quickly from Darcy. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is at the buffet watching Kitty quaff a huge glass of wine and having the glass immediately refilled. She is joined by Caroline Bingley who also looks at Kitty disapprovingly. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Elizabeth. Let me recommend you as a friend not to give too much confidence to all of the assertions your friend Mr Wickham might make. He is indeed a charming man, but one should never forget from where he is descended. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His lack of trustworthiness and descent appear by your account to be the same thing, CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please excuse my interterence, it was kindly meant. ГўВЂВў A breathless Mr Collins appears. COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Mr Darcy, of Pemberley in Derbyshire? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe so. COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I must make myself known to him immediately! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But sir - COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is the nephew of my esteemed patroness, Lady Catherine. ELIZABETH (SURPRISED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is? Mr Collins starts making his way determinedly towards Darcy. Г‚ВЂВў ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mr Collins! He'll consider it an IMPERTINENCE --
Elizabeth watches from a distance, with acute embarrassment, as Collins interrupts Darcy. Darcy does not notice him so Collins raises his voice. COLLINS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy! The room around him stops. Darcy is surprised and turns round. In dumbshow we see Darcy is horrified by Collins' obsequiousness, during the conversation Collins points Elizabeth out to Darcy. CAROLINE BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What interesting relatives you have, Miss Bennet. Elizabeth walks away into another room. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other room, where Mary is singing badly at the piano. Elizabeth is horrified. She turns to leave only to see Mr Bennet looking on. He winces as Mary misses a high note. Mary finishes the song with an off key flourish. Polite applause. Mary smiles and prepares for another song. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to do something? Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bennet walks over to the piano. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary dear, you've delighted us long enough. MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they asked for another song. Mr Bennet shuts the lid. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the other young ladies have a turn. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Charlotte and Lizzie are sat together. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps my family have made a competition to see who can expose themselves to the most ridicule. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, at least Bingley has not noticed. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look over and see Jane and Bingley dancing. Bingley clearly besotted by Jane.
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Yes. I think he likes her very much. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But does she like him? There are few of us who are secure enough to be really in love without proper encouragement. Bingley likes her enormously but might not do more if she does not help him on. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is just shy and modest. If he does not perceive her regard he is a fool. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are all fools in love. He does not know her character as we do. She should move fast. Snap him up. There is plenty of time for us to get to know them after we're married - Elizabeth looks over the dancefloor to see Lydia dancing with a soldier. she's a little drunk, and very flirtatious. He says something; she shrieks with laughter. CUT TO;

dialogues.speaker: THE BALL 47
dialogues.text: Elizabeth sits at the side of the dance-floor. She looks at Mrs Bennet dancing in outrageous fashion. Cut to later: Lydia is getting more and more leery with a group of soldiers, Elizabeth walks away in embarrasment only to see Mr Collins smiling at her from across the room. Cut to: Elizabeth dancing joylessly with the excruciating Mr Collins, as she turns in the dance she sees Darcy look on with obvious disdain. Cut to: much later, the band are exhausted, guests are leaving. The staff are asleep on their feet. Elizabeth almost alone watching her parents dancing almost the only people left on the dance floor, Kitty is asleep over Elizabeth's lap. This is a never- ending nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Day light creeps through the curtains. Mrs Bennet is sprawled on a sofa. Lydia completely drunk. Kitty asleep. Jane sitting demurely. Collins looking longingly at Elizabeth. Mrs Bennet is holding court, whilst the footmen behind are literally ready to drop. Bingley is standing, the perfect host, but obviously willing the ГўВЂВў Bennets to leave.
MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have never had such a good time in my life. Mr Bingley you must have such a ball once a month at least. Caroline who is standing with her brother, yawns ostentatiously. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother. I really think it is time to go. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be impertinent. our hosts are perfectly happy with our company, are you not, Mr Bingley? I hope I can entice you to Longbourn to sample our hospitality. We would make sure you had 3 or 4 courses at least. She holds out her glass for a top up and carries on.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So tell me Mr Bingley. Whom did you like least of all your guests this evening? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. This is enough. Darcy looking down at Elizabeth from a staircase. He turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bennet's are squeezed into their carriage. It is light outside. Only Mrs Bennet is awake but the lack of an audience does not stop her from talking. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allowing for new carriages, dresses etcetera, etcetera. We will be having a wedding here at Netherfield in less than three months, if you ask me. Mr Bennet? Mr Bennet! 5o INT. BREAKFAST ROOM - LONGBOURNE - DAY. 50 The Bennets eat in silence. Jane.yawns. Mrs Bennet moans she is hungover. Mr Collins comes in in a state of agitation. They look at him. He sits, hesitates, then ASKS: 0
is MR COLLINS Mrs Bennet I was hoping, if it would not trouble you, that I might solicit a private audience with Miss Elizabeth in the course of the morning. Elizabeth is open mouthed. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Yes. Certainly - Lizzy would be very happy indeed. Please -- go ahead. No time like the present. Everyone. Out. Mr Collins would like a private audience with your sister. Everyone looks in amazement. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. I beg you. Mr Collins can have nothing to say to me.that anybody need not hear. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nonsense, Lizzy. I desire you-will stay where you are. Everyone else, to the drawing room. Mr Bennet. ГўВЂВў MR BENNET But... MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now! Mrs Bennet makes sure everyone leaves, winks at Mr Collins then shuts the door before Elizabeth has time to do anything. Elizabeth looks at Mr Collins who looks at her in earnest. There is a horrible pause of intense embarrassment. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Miss Elizabeth, you can hardly doubt the purpose of my discourse. My attentions have been too marked to be mistaken. Almost as soon as I entered the house I singled you out as the companion of my future life. Elizabeth stares at him, astonished. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before I am run away with my feelings perhaps I may state my reasons for marrying. Firstly, that it is the duty of a clergyman to set the example of matrimony in his parish. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: S0.
dialogues.text: MR COLLINS (cont'd) Secondly, that I am convinced it will add greatly to my happiness, and, thirdly, ГўВЂВў that it is at the urging of my esteemed patroness Lady Catherine that I select a wife. We here a kick and Kitty screach from behind the door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BENNET, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: sshhh. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My object in coming to Longbourn was to choose such a one from amongst Mr Bennet's daughters, for as you know I am next in the entail of the estate and such an alliance will surely make amends for this. (drops to his knee) And now nothing remains for me but to assure you in the most animated language of the violence of my affections. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Collins - MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
