dialogues.text: And that no reproach on the subject of fortune will cross my lips once we are ГўВЂВў married. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are too hasty, sir! You forget that I have made no answer. MR COLLINS (UNPERTURBED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must add, that Lady Catherine will thoroughly approve, when I speak to her of your modesty, economy and other amiable qualities. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I am honoured by your proposal, but regret I must decline it. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (momentarily taken aback, but RECOVERING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know ladies have their pretty little ways, and don't seek to seem too eager - ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in some desperation) Mr Collins, I am perfectly serious. You could not make me happy and I'm convinced I'm the last woman in the world who could make you happy.
ГўВЂВў MR COLLINS (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I 'flatter myself, cousin, that your refusal is merely a natural delicacy. Besides, you should take into account that despite your manifold attractions it is by no means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made to you - ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising, deeply affronted) Mr Collins - MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I must conclude that you simply seek to increase my love by suspense, according to the usual practice of elegant females. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir! I am not the sort of female to torment a respectable man. Please understand me - I cannot accept you! Elizabeth storms out of the room and out of the house. Mrs Bennet crashes in through another door, hot on the tail of Elizabeth. Г‚ВЂВў MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Declined indeed! The headstrong, foolish CHILD- COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, but... Head strong? MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - we shall have this little hiccup dealt with immediately, Mr Collins. Mrs Bennet goes chases after Elizabeth. Mr Collins watches through a window as Elizabeth is chased by her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Bennet marches into the library. Mr Bennet looks up in shock. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Mr Bennet. We are all in a uproar. You must come and make Lizzy marry Mr Collins, for she vows she will not have him. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bennet starter at Mrs Bennet blankley.
MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Collins, Mr Collins has proposed to Lizzie. But Lizzy declares she will not have him, and now the danger is Mr Collins may not have Lizzy. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what am I to do? Mrs Bennet drags Mr Bennet to his feet. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak to Lizzy. They march to find Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bennet and Mrs Bennet confront Elizabeth, who has been waiting in the hallway. Perhaps the other girls form an audience from the stairs, Mr Collins looks on sheepishly from the breakfast room. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her that you insist upon them marrying. Г‚ВЂВў LIZZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa, please - '. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will have this house! LIZZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't marry him! MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll save your sisters from destitution! LIZZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't! - MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back now and say you've changed your mind! LIZZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! 0 MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of your family! LIZZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't make me!
MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bennet, say something! MR BENNET (TO LIZZIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, your mother insists on you marrying Mr Collins.- MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, or I shall never see her again? MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Lizzie. From this day on you must be a stranger to one of your parents - MRS BENNET (TO LIZZIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - who will maintain you when your father is dead? MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother will never see you again if you do not marry Mr Collins, and I will never see you again if you do. MRS BENNET MR BENNET' ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, papa. Elizabeth turns around and walks into the drawing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth enters the drawing room. In the drawing room, Mary is trying to read, through the family din. Jane sits very still. Her face is white. There's a letter in her hand. Mrs Bennet charges in, Lydia and Kitty in tow, and speaks to anyone who will listen. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, ungrateful child! I shall never speak to her again! Not that I have much pleasure in talking to anybody. People who suffer as I do from nervous complaints can have no inclination for talking. Nobody can tell what I suffer... She jabbers on but her voice fades. We're with Jane, re- reading the letter. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong, Jane? Close on Jane's pale face. She's staring at the letter.
MRS BENNET (DISTANT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it is always so. Those who complain are never pitied...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingley, Caroline and Darcy sit grimly in a carriage which drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darcy looks severe and stern, Caroline can't help a little smirk on her face. Bingley looks back longingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Jane in bed. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. What would take him from Netherfield? Why would he not know when he was to return? JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў I have no reserves from you. Jane passes Elizabeth the letter. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Mr Darcy is impatient to see his sister and we are scarcely less eager to meet her again. I really do not think Georgina Darcy has her equal for beauty, elegance and accomplishments, so much so I must hope to hereafter call her my sister. It is my duty to indulge you in no hope in this respect for your own self." JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that not clear enough? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bingley sees that her brother is in love with you and is gone with him to persuade him otherwise. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I know her to be incapable of wilfully deceiving anyone. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў He loves you, Jane. Do not give up. Go to our aunt and uncle's in London. (MORE)
ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it be known you are there and I am sure he will come to you. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is in a carriage. Mrs Bennet kisses her goodbye through the window as all the Bennets look on. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give my love to my sister. And try not to be so much of a burden, dear. Jane's carriage moves away and the family wave. Mr Bennet talks to Elizabeth. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Jane. However, a girl likes to be crossed in love now and then. It gives her something to think of, and a sort of distinction among her companions. ELIZABETH (DRYLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure that will cheer her up,Papa. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your turn now, Lizzie. Since you've turned down Mr Collins you're free to go off and be jilted yourself. What about Mr Wickham? He is a pleasant fellow and would do the job credibly. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, but a less agreeable man would satisfy me. We must not all expect Jane's good fortune. MR KENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, it's a comfort to know that whatever might befall you, you have an affectionate mother who will be sure to make the most of it. A small smile from Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is making the bed and tidying Jane's belongings. There is a knock at the door and Charlotte enters. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Elizabeth, I've come here to tell you the news.
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў What news? CHARLOTTE (DEFIANTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Collins and I are engaged to be married. A stunned pause. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Engaged? CHARLOTTE (TIMIDLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mind, do you? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... (tries to recover) Of course not. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked for my hand this morning .and I accepted him. Elizabeth looks quite faint. Charlotte sits on the bed. Elizabeth, after a pause, sits down beside her. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see you're surprised - coming so soon after his wishing to marry you... ELIZABETH (WEAKLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a romantic, you know. I ask only a comfortable home, and considering Mr Collin's character, and situation in life, I am convinced that my chance of happiness with him is as fair as most people can hope for. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's all you expect? CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For women in our situation, what choice is there? ELIZABETH (PASSIONATELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't speak like that, Charlotte!
CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў - to become an old maid, at best tolerated, at worst a burden, dependent on the kindness of others? Or to seek the protection of marriage. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we only have two choices? CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. An appalled silence. Elizabeth gazes at her closest friend. Charlotte has recovered herself. she now looks cool and composed - unnervingly so. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can still change your mind, Charlotte. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) I'm twenty-seven years old. We hear the sound of the militia drums...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The militia are leaving Meryton. Hundreds of soldiers and officers in the red coats marching out of the village to the sound of pipes and drums. The villagers are out to bid them farewell. Lydia and Kitty run through the crowds very distraught. They find Elizabeth coming in the other direction. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too dreadful! They're leaving for Brighton. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them? KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got the call this morning. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a word of warning! Lydia wails. Elizabeth searches the red coats for Wickham. She spots him, he glances across at her, she gives a pathetic wave and he's gone. Lydia and Kitty chase the last of the officers, leaving Elizabeth alone. She walks into the post office. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: C 60 INT. VILLAGE POST OFFICE
dialogues.text: The Postmaster hands a letter to Elizabeth. Elizabeth opens it and reads it. POSTMASTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad news, Miss? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could not be worse. I have been invited to possibly the very last place on earth I would like to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth comes out of the post office to reveal... Time has passed, the now deserted village is covered in a thick blanket of snow. A lonely Elizabeth walks away totally despondent. 62 EXT. HUNSFORD PARSONAGE - KENT - DAY. 6< Charlotte's new home is a smallish but charming rectory in Kent. Charlotte greets Elizabeth, kissing her warmly. ГўВЂВў Mr Collins bows as he ushers her in. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to our humble abode...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a coop containing hens of various descriptions ...a.pig-stye...a vegetable patch...a rose bower. Charlotte and Mr Collins are showing Elizabeth round the place. MR COLLINS (POINTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And from here we have a good view of Rosings Park, where we are honoured to dine at least twice a week. Her ladyship's carriage is regularly ordered for us. I should say, one of her ladyship's carriages, for she has several. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, I think our guest is tired after her journey. Come on, Lizzie, let's get some tea. T
MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў My wife encourages me to spend as much time in the garden as possible, for the sake of my health. A beat. Lizzie glances at Charlotte, who remains impassive. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I plan many improvements, of course. (points to house) I intend. to throw out a bow there, and plant a lime walk. (sharp look at Lizzie) Oh yes, I flatter myself that any young lady would be happy to be the mistress of such a house. A tiny nod from Elizabeth. She understands perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie and Charlotte are at last alone. They sit down, with a certain relief, in a charming little parlour that faces the front of the house. Charlotte pours out tea. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў We shall not be disturbed here, for this parlour is for my own particular use. (A BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Lizzie, it's such a pleasure, to run my own home! A flash of understanding between them.

dialogues.speaker: MR COLLINS, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Charlotte! Come here! Charlotte jumps up and rushes to the window. ELIZABETH (ALARMED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: MR COLLINS, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Charlotte! ELIZABETH (JUMPS UP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has the pig escaped? Lizzie joins her at the window. outside in the lane, Mr Collins stands, bowing, at a carriage. Г‚ВЂВў CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its all right. Its just Lady Catherine.
They both burst out laughing. Just for a moment, the ГўВЂВў atmosphere is eased. CHARLOTTE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, how are things concerning Mr Wickham? Elizabeth's face changes. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have not heard from Mr Wickham since the regiment left for Brighton, but I am informed by Lydia who keeps a breast of all matters military that he does very well. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Lizzie. we hear Mr Collins rushing back into the house, and running up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Great news! Great news! He comes into the room, breathlessly excited. COLLINS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў We have an invitation to visit Rosings this evening from Lady Catherine de Bourgh. Elizabeth is not overcome with enthusiasm. COLLINS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not make yourself uneasy, my dear cousin, about your apparel. Just put on that which is best among your clothes and Lady Catherine will not think the worse of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, Charlotte and Mr Collins walk hurriedly across the lawns towards the great house. Beyond the toparied hedges the grey building looms ominously above them. It is grand without being elegant. COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the most extraordinary sights in all Europe, is it not. The glazing alone cost upwards of twenty thousand pounds. 0
Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Collins, Charlotte and Elizabeth are led up a vast stairway which is painted with visions of hell. Elizabeth stops in front of a painting of a devil. She stares at it, It seem to speak, but she realizes the voice is Collins chiding her. COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as the devil) This way!

dialogues.speaker: TNT. SALON
dialogues.text: The salon at Rosings is spectacularly grand; hideously so. Heavy furniture, rows of servants. The three guests are shown in by the footman. Again Mr Collins scrapes the floor with his bow. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Ladyship. (to the daughter) Miss de Bourg. Lady Catherine is a haughty, bossy woman. Pretty ГўВЂВў unspeakable, really. Her daughter is a sickly, irr looking creature. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you are Elizabeth Bennet. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, your ladyship. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking her up and down) Hmm. (indicates her daughter) This is my daughter. CHARLOTTE (EAGERLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very kind of you to ask us to dine, Lady Catherine. Lady Catherine ignores her. MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to Lizzie) The chimneypiece alone cost Г‚ВЈ400. But Lizzie doesn't hear. Darcy walks into the room. Lizzie freezes. When he sees Lizzie he, too, falters, and recovers himself. Another man (Fitzwilliam) is with him.
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Mr Darcy! What are you doing here? MR COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy! (another deep bow) I had no idea we would have the honour... A stiff bow from Darcy, who looks at Mr Collins as if he's something brought in by the dog. He turns to Lizzie, trying to collect himself. DARCY (BOWS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bennet...I'm staying here. LADY CATHERINE (SURPRISED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know my nephew? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, madam, I had the pleasure of meeting him in Hertfordshire. Darcy's friend Fitzwilliam, a much more easy-going chap, introduces himself. FITZWILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Colonel Fitzwilliam. How do you do? He bows. Lizzie returns his smile gratefully. They move towards the dining room. Mr Collins leans towards Lizzie. MR COLLINS (WHISPERING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Mr Darcy is as good as engaged to Miss de Bourg? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Miss Bingley will be disappointed to hear that. (looks at the girl, and whispers to charlotte) What a sickly, cross little thing! Oh yes, they should suit each other very well. Charlotte smiles back, a little fearfully. She's more intimidated by Rosings than Elizabeth is, and indeed has more at stake. 68 INT. DINING ROOM - ROSINGS - NIGHT. f 9 The dining room is laid for a very grand dinner -- foot waiting, thousands of candles.
Lady Catherine seats herself at the head of the table. The guests wait for their orders. Г‚ВЂВў LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sit there and you sit there. Mr Collins! You can't sit next to your wife! After some awkward shuffling around they all sit down. Lizzie, much to her discomfort, finds herself sitting next to Darcy. There is a pause. MR DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust your family is in good health, Miss Bennet? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are, thank you. (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My eldest sister is currently in London, perhaps you happened to see her there? MR DARCY (AWKWARD PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been fortunate enough, no. Lizzie looks at him. He colours slightly. Lady Catherine addresses Lizzie in a loud voice, from the head of the table. Г‚ВЂВў LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you play the pianoforte, Miss Bennet? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little, ma'am, and very poorly. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Do you draw? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not at all. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sisters, do they draw? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not one. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is very strange. But I suppose you had no opportunity. Your mother should have taken you to town every spring for the benefit of the masters. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother would have no objection but my father hates London.
LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Has your governess left you? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We never had a governess. Mr Collins squirms in embarrassment. Darcy watches Elizabeth, keenly. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No governess? Five daughters brought up at home without a governess, I never heard such a thing! Your mother must have been quite a slave to your education. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (can't help smiling at this) Not at all, Lady Catherine. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm. Are any of your younger sisters out? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. All. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All! What, five out at once? Very odd! ГўВЂВў And you only the second - the younger ones out before the elders are married! Your youngest sisters must be very young. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, my youngest is not sixteen. But I think it would be very hard on younger sisters, not to have their share of amusement because the elder is still unmarried. And to be kept back on such a motive! It would hardly encourage sisterly affection. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upon my word, you give your opinion very decidedly for so young a person. Pray, what is your age? ELIZABETH (SMILES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With three younger sisters grown up, your Ladyship can hardly expect me to own to P C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: it. Lady Catherine looks astonished. Mr Collins shifts in his seat. Mr Darcy glances sharply - in fact, admiringly - at Lizzie. She's enjoying herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner is over and they are drinking coffee. Darcy moves towards Elizabeth but Lady Catherine interrupts, by shouting from her seat. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Miss Bennet, and play for us! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I beg you - LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For music is my delight. In fact there are few people in England who have more true enjoyment of music than myself, or better natural taste. If I had ever learnt, I should have been a great proficient. (INDICATES DAUGHTER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So would Anne, if her health would have allowed her. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, I told you I play poorly - ГўВЂВў MR COLLINS (HISSES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come come, Elizabeth, her ladyship demands it! Lizzie reluctantly sits down at the piano and starts to play. Lady Catherine takes no notice and talks loudly over the music. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does Georgina get along, Darcy? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She plays very well. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope she practises. No excellence can be acquired without constant practice. I have told Mrs Collins this. (turns to Charlotte) Though you have no instrument of your own you are very welcome to come to Rosings and play on the piano in the housekeeper's room. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, your ladyship.
LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў You would be in nobody's way", you know, in that part of the house. Darcy flinches at her bad manners. He moves away to the piano where Lizzie is playing - not that terribly well, it must be said. A moment passes. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to frighten me, Mr Darcy, by coming in all your state to hear me, but I won't be alarmed even though your sister does play so well. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am well enough acquainted with you, Miss Bennet, to know I cannot alarm you even should I wish it. A beat. They eye each other warily. Colonel Fitzwilliam joins them. FITZWILLIAM (INDICATING DARCY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was my friend like, in Hertfordshire? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў You really care to know? The colonel nods. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prepare yourself for something very dreadful. (STOPS PLAYING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first time I saw him, at the Assembly, he danced with nobody at all - even though gentlemen were scarce and there was more than one young lady who was sitting down without a partner. DARCY (COLOURING )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew nobody beyond my own party. ELIZABETH (SMILES SWEETLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True, and nobody can be introduced in a ballroom. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fitzwilliam! Come here and talk to us! 0 Fitzwilliam moves away. Darcy and Elizabeth are alone.
DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not have the talent of conversing easily with people I have never met before. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should take your aunt's advice and practice. Ouch! Darcy flinches. Lizzie turns away from him and carries on playing. Darcy gazes at the curve of her neck. She plays a false note, stumbles, and grimly carries on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is writing a letter in the drawing room. She starts "Dear Jane..:" The doorbell rings in the background, she thinks nothing of it and continues. The maid opens the door to the drawing room and Mr Darcy enters. ELIZABETH (ASTONISHED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy! An awkward pause. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, do be seated. (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid Mr and Mrs Collins are gone on business to the village. A pause. What on earth does Mr Darcy want? He paces up and down. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a charming house. I believe my aunt did a great deal to it when Mr Collins first arrived. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe so -- and she could not have bestowed her kindness on a more grateful SUBJECT-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another pause. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Collins seems very fortunate in his choice of wife. Г‚ВЂВў
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is indeed lucky to have found one of the few sensible women who would have accepted him. Darcy sits down. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I call for some tea? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Thankyou. The sound of the front door, and voices. Darcy jumps up. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, Miss Bennet. It's been a pleasure. He bows to her and leaves. Elizabeth sits there, bemused and intrigued. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte, in the hallway, taking off her bonnet. Darcy hurries past her, with a swift bow, and leaves abruptly. Charlotte gazes after him in surprise. ГўВЂВў Charlotte heads to the drawing room where she find Elizabeth sitting, bemused. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What on earth have you done to poor Mr Darcy? ELIZABETH. I have no idea. 73 She truly doesn't. Charlotte gives Elizabeth a look 73

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday service is over and worshippers are leaving the " church. Mr Collins, in his vestments, obeises himself to Lady Catherine, who is sweeping out with her miserable- looking daughter and downtrodden governess. Elizabeth joins Colonel Fitzwilliam. They walk down the path together. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long do you plan to stay in Kent, Colonel? FITZWILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as Darcy chooses. I am at his disposal.
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do imagine your cousin brought you down with him chiefly to have someone to order around. I wonder he does not marry and secure a lasting convenience of that kind. FITZWILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She would be a lucky woman. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? FITZWILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darcy is a most loyal companion. From what I heard, on our journey here, he recently came to the rescue of one of his friends just in time. Darcy, waylaid by various people, comes out of the church. His eyes search for Elizabeth. He sees her with Fitzwilliam and hesitates. Too late! Mr Collins steps up to him and engages him in conversation. Elizabeth stops, at the churchyard gate. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? Г‚ВЂВў FITZWILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He saved the man from an imprudent marriage. ELIZABETH (FALTERING SLIGHTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was the man? FITZWILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His closest friend. Mr Bingley. A silence. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Mr Darcy give you his reasons for this interference? FITZWILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were apparently strong objections to the lady. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of objections? Her lack of fortune? FITZWILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it was her family that was considered unsuitable.
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he separated them? FITZWILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe so. I know nothing else. Elizabeth grows pale. She turns to look at Darcy who is joined by his aunt. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish Mr Darcy and all his friends well in finding partners suitable to their very high standards. Good morning, Col. Fitzwilliam. 76 Elizabeth see that Collinses are still busy with their parishioners and slips away. Darcy sees her from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie walks across the park - anywhere, she hardly cares. She is in a turmoil of misery and fury. How could Darcy do such a terrible thing! It starts to rain. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў A Grecian summer house by the lake. The rain is no bucketing down. Lizzie hurries into the summer house and sits down, heavily, on a bench. Her poor sister; Lizzie gazes in despair at the rain- lashed landscape. A man approaches, across the park. He draws nearer. It's Darcy. Elizabeth stiffens. He's hurrying towards her. Sodden, breathless, he comes into the. summer house. He is in a state of agitation - far too agitated to notice her upset face. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bennet, I have struggled in vain but I can bear it no longer ... . The past months have been a torment... He pauses, unable to speak. Elizabeth stares at him in astonishment. He struggles on. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to Rosings with the single object of seeing you...I had to see you... ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Me?
DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў I've fought against my better judgement, my family's expectation... (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inferiority of your birth.. .my rank and circumstance... (STUMBLINGLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: all those things.. .but I'm willing to put them aside... and ask you to end my agony... ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand... DARCY (WITH PASSION)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you. Most ardently. Elizabeth stares at him. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please do me the honour of accepting my hand. A silence. Elizabeth struggles with the most painful confusion of feeling. Finally she recovers. ELIZABETH (VOICE SHAKING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I appreciate the struggle you have been through, and I am very sorry to have caused you pain. Believe me, it was unconsciously done. A silence. Gathering her shawl, she gets to her feet. DARCY (STARES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this your reply? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you laughing at me? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you rejecting me? ELIZABETH (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure that the feelings which, as you've told me, have hindered your regard, will help you in overcoming it.
A terrible silence, as this sinks in. Neither of them can ГўВЂВў move. At last, Darcy speaks. He is very pale. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might I ask why, with so little endeavour at civility, I am thus repulsed? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trembling with emotion) I might as well enquire why, with so. evident a design of insulting me, you chose to tell me that you liked me against your better judgement. If I was uncivil, that was some excuse - DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, I didn't mean - ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I have other reasons, you know I have! DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What reasons? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think that anything might tempt me to accept the man who has ruined, perhaps for ever, the happiness of a most beloved sister? Silence. Darcy looks as if he's been struck across the face. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you deny it, Mr Darcy? That you separated a young couple who loved each other, exposing your friend to the censure of the world for caprice, and my sister to its derision for disappointed hopes, and involving them both in misery of the acutest kind? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not deny it. ELIZABETH (BLURTS OUT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you do it? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I believed your sister indifferent to him. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Indifferent?
DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў I watched them most carefully, and realized his attachment was much deeper than hers. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because she's shy! DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingley too is modest, and was persuaded that she didn't feel strongly for him. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you suggested it! DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did it for his own good. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister hardly shows her true feelings to me! (pause, takes a breath) I suppose you suspect that his fortune had some bearing on the matter? DARCY (SHARPLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I wouldn't do your sister the Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: dishonour. Though it was suggested - (STOPS) ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was made perfectly clear that-an advantageous marriage... (STOPS) ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did my sister give that impression? DARCY -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! An awkward pause. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was, however, I have to admit... the matter of your family - ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our want of connection? Mr Bingley didn't vex himself about that! Г‚ВЂВў DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it was more than that.
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How, sir? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause, very uncomfortable) It pains me to say this, but it was the lack of propriety shown by your mother, your three younger sisters - even, on occasion, your father. Forgive me. Lizzie blushes. He has hit home. Darcy paces up and down. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your sister -- I must exclude from this... Darcy stops and gazes at her. He is in turmoil. Elizabeth glares at him, in a blaze of fury and misery. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about Mr Wickham? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Wickham? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What excuse can you give for your behavior to him? Г‚ВЂВў DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take an eager interest in that gentleman's concerns! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me of his misfortunes. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, his misfortunes have been very great indeed! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have ruined his chances, and yet treat him with sarcasm? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is your opinion of me! Thank you for explaining so fully. Perhaps these offences might have been overlooked, if your pride had not been hurt - ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pride? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - by my honesty in admitting scruples about our relationship. (MORE)
DARCY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your circumstances? Г‚ВЂВў ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And those are the words of a gentleman? From the first moment I met you, your arrogance and conceit, your selfish distain of the feelings of others, made me realize that you were the last man in the world I could ever be prevailed upon to marry. Darcy recoils, as if slapped. A terrible silence. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, madam, for taking up so much of your time. He leaves, abruptly. Elizabeth watches him stride away, through the rain. What has she done? She bitterly bursts into tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth comes in soaked to the skin. Charlotte runs to her. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was caught somewhat off-guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte attends to Elizabeth.who has changed and is drying her hair, a shawl around her shoulders. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I call the doctor? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Charlotte, I shall be quite all right. Please, give Lady de Bourgh my apologies. You must not keep her waiting. Mr Collins clatters up the stairs. COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (popping his head around the DOOR)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. We shall be late! Г‚ВЂВў
Charlotte leaves, reluctantly, and goes downstairs. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later; The sound of the front door closing. Elizabeth sits down, heavily, on the bed. She walks downstairs and enters the drawing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is in the drawing room, she looks at a book on the table. It is Fordyce's Sermons. She puts it down and walks to the mirror and stares at herself. After a moment suddenly Darcy's face appears. She freezes. They stare at each other without speaking. Finally... DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to leave you this. He places a letter on the table behind her. Elizabeth does not turn but watches him through the mirror. DARCY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to renew the sentiments which were so disgusting to you, but to address the two offenses you have laid against me. I had not long been in Hertfordshire before I saw that Bingley Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: preferred your eldest sister. I observed my friend's behaviour attentively and I could perceive that his partiality for Miss Bennet was beyond what I have ever witnessed in him. Elizabeth cannot bring herself to look at Darcy. She stares at her own reflection as he speaks. DARCY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet when I observed your sister .1 detected no symptom of peculiar regard, and witnessed only the families coarse appetite for having their daughters married favorably. And so in London, perhaps erroneously, I persuaded him of the unfitness of the match citing your sisters coolness towards him. We zoom in on Elizabeth's reflection. DARCY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was unknowingly done and though the motives which governed me may to you appear naturally insufficient, they were done to protect a friend. As to the other ГўВЂВў more serious matter..
As Elizabeth turns she realises Darcy has gone. Darcy's voice carries.

dialogues.speaker: DARCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "My father provided for Mr Wickham a valuable living. Elizabeth tears open the envelope, her hands shaking, and reads the letter, as Darcy's voice carries on.

dialogues.speaker: DARCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "But upon his death, however, Mr Wickham told me that he had no intention of taking orders and would I recompense him to the tune of Г‚ВЈ3000 so he could go to town and study the law. We circle Elizabeth as she reads.

dialogues.speaker: DARCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This I did, though by now I had some doubts about his character. These were confirmed by reports that he had sunk into a life of idleness, gambling and dissipation. The money was soon used up, whereupon he wrote demanding more money which I refused, whereupon he severed all Г‚ВЂВў ACQUAINTANCE"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding the letter she looks out of the window to see Darcy riding away. DARCY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "But last summer he was unwillingly obtruded on my notice when he connived a relationship with my sister whom he persuaded to be in love with him and made her consent to an elopement. She was but fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darcy rides off.

dialogues.speaker: DARCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mr Wickham's prime objective was her inheritance of thirty thousand pounds but hope of revenging me was a strong inducement. I was lucky enough to persuade my sister of her folly. I hope this goes someway to mitigating my behaviour in your eyes. If you doubt my word please have it confirmed by my Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cousin Fitzwilliam.
ГўВЂВў 77 INT. DRAWING ROOM -- HUNSFORD - LATER - DAY 7 Elizabeth with the letter. Charlotte walks in. Elizabeth is shaking. CHARLOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzy: Are you alright? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not know. I hardly know myself. Elizabeth looks at Charlotte utterly shaken.

dialogues.speaker: TNT/EXT. CARRIAGE/CHEAPSIDE
dialogues.text: Elizabeth riding in a carriage through Cheapside, reading the letter.

dialogues.speaker: DARCY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: P.S. As we shall never meet again, I wish you all happiness in the future. Elizabeth looks out at the high warehouse building and the bustle of trade. There is no horizon. is 79 INT. GARDINERS HOUSE - CHEAPSIDE - DAY. 7 Mrs Gardiner, the girls' kindly aunt, is taking Elizabeth's coat from her. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How fortunate, you are here just in time to catch everybody coming through from Longbourn. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is Jane? Mrs Gardiner smiles sadly. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is outside. Through a window Elizabeth sees Jane sitting quietly alone at her needle work. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: CHEAPSIDE
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Jane sit together in the small walled garden.
Jane is all smiles, but behind her eyes is a sadness unseen before. Elizabeth is desperate to unburden herself ГўВЂВў but feels unable. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am quite over him, Lizzie. If he passed in the street I would hardly notice. London is so diverting... ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oh Jane... JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its true! What with the theatre and... But tell me, what news from Kent? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Everything as you might imagine. Elizabeth tries to smile. There is a crash as all the Bennet's arrive at the house. Kitty rushes into the garden crying her eyes out, she is followed by Lydia and Mrs Bennet. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie, tell mama, tell her! LYDIA (SMUGLY) Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Forster has invited me. KITTY (WAILS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't she ask me as well? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty, what's happened? LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - because she likes me better. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just as much right as Lydia - MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, if I could but go to Brighton - KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and more so, because I'm two years older! Elizabeth looks to Jane. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia has been invited to Brighton with the Foresters.
MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў A little sea-bathing would set me up very NICELY- LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall dine with the officers every night! An anguished wail from Kitty. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure I cried for two days when Colonel Millar's regiment went away. thought I should have broke my heart. LIZZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother! Are you all mad? She glares at them, deeply upset -- by them, by everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth has found a quiet corner with her father. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please Papa, don't let her go! MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia will never be easy till she has exposed herself in some public place or other, and we can never expect her to do it with so little inconvenience as under the present circumstances. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great emotion) If you, dear father, will not take the trouble to check her, she will be fixed forever as the silliest and most determined flirt who ever made her family ridiculous. And Kitty will follow, as she always does. MR KENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall have no peace until she goes. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (really angry now) Peace! Is that all you care about? MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Forster is a sensible man and will keep her out of any real mischief, and she is far too poor to be an object of prey to anyone.
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, its dangerous! - MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure the officers will find women better worth their while. Let us hope, in fact, that her stay in Brighton will teach her her own insignificance. At any rate she can hardly grow any worse, without authorizing us to lock her up for the rest of her life. Elizabeth gazes at her father - will nothing touch him? He gave up on his daughter long ago. For this, just now, she hates him. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder our family is treated with contempt. She leaves, tears stinging her eyes. Her father looks puzzled at her outburst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bennet follows Elizabeth in. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, at least the house will be quieter. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wish to be stuck with such a foolish family any longer, with your constant talk of men and marriages. Surely there is more to life. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie dear, you would be very welcome to accompany us? MR GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. We plan to journey through the Peak District. You'd be most welcome. MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the glories of nature! What are men, compared to rocks and mountains? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, men are either eaten up with arrogance or stupidity. And if they're amiable they're so easily led that they have no minds of their own whatsoever.
MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care, my love, that savours strongly of bitterness. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they bring nothing but heartache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As usual Elizabeth and Jane share a bed. They lie next to each other in the darkness ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw Mr Darcy when I was in Rosings. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you not tell me. Did he mention Mr Bingley. Pause. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He did not. Elizabeth has never felt more alone in the company of her sister. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ravishing landscape of savage and romantic beauty - scudding clouds, mountains, wild rocky outcrops. Elizabeth is walking freely, the wind in her hair. As she nears the peak of a promontory, Mr and Mrs Gardiner are below making their way towards her. They smile at her. She strides off determined to reach the very top. When she gets there she stands with her arms outstretched, her head back laughing into the wind. The view is magnificent. She breathes deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An establishing shot of Lambton, a charming market town. Through the window of an inn we see Elizabeth and Mr and Mrs Gardiner at a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the inn, the Gardiner's and Elizabeth are eating supper. An air of high spirits. At the next table, another amiable tourist couple are also tucking into their food. Г‚ВЂВў
WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў (indicating her husband) He's been taking the waters at Buxton. (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasn't done him a jot of good. HER HUSBAND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we've had a fine time, haven't we dear? WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've visited Chatsworth, Dovedale, PEMBERLEY - MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pemberley? WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just two miles from here. close, very close, on Lizzie's face. HER HUSBAND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the best houses in the country. MR GARDINER (TO ELIZABETH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you acquainted with the owner, Mr ГўВЂВў Darcy? MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we shall go there tomorrow, Lizzie. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would rather stay here. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here? ELIZABETH (VERY UNCOMFORTABLE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must own that I'm tired of great houses. All those carpets and curtains. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you liked Chatsworth. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it is anything like Mr Darcy, I am sure I will not be able to bear it. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, come, Lizzie. WOMAN Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grounds alone are worth a visit.
MR GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us not make a fuss. If the girl does not want to go there is little point in persuading her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is preparing for bed. The chambermaid fills her washbowl and starts to leave. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear that Pemberley is not far from here. MAID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, madam. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see something of the owner, do you, in town? MAID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for some months, madam, for he's still in London, I believe. A pause. Close on Elizabeth's face. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 88 EXT. PEMBERLEY - DAY. 8n The carriage enters the gates of Pemberley. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad you changed your mind. Elizabeth is alert, her eyes bright with curiosity. The parkland is wild and rocky. Deer graze; rooks wheel in the sky. A sense of freedom and liberation. As the carriage drives over the top of a hill, close on Elizabeth's face. She gasps. The Gardiners gasp. A huge, wide shot of Pemberley House. It's vast, breathtakingly beautiful, set in great boulder-strewn park lands. A mansion built of golden stone, glowing in the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth walks through the magnificent grounds. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine being mistress of all this. It is as big as all Cheapside. Elizabeth is lost in admiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and the Gardiners are being taken on the tour by the housekeeper, Mrs Reynolds, who witters on in the background with descriptions of each room. Elizabeth is apart and we witness the exquisite house from her point of view. A book lies open, on a reading desk, Elizabeth turns it over to read the title. MRS GARDINER (TO ELIZABETH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep up. They walk through room after amazing room: a breath- taking library, an unbelievable staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The huge picture gallery. Elizabeth is apart from the rest looking at the pictures she stops by a painting of Darcy. She looks at it thoughtfully but is interrupted by Mrs Reynolds and the Gardiners who are following her. MRS REYNOLDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my master - Mr Darcy. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handsome face. Lizzie, is it a true likeness of him? MRS REYNOLDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this young lady know Mr Darcy? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a little. MRS REYNOLDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do you not think him a handsome man, Miss? ELISABETH (THOUGHTFULLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes I suppose he is. Mrs Reynolds moves the Gardiners on to another painting, but Elizabeth stays, staring at Darcy's image. MRS REYNOLDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is his sister, Miss Georgians. She plays and sings all day long. We realize that in the distance we have heard music. Elizabeth is still gazing at the portrait of Darcy, then suddenly snaps out of her reverie, as she processes Mrs REYNOLDS SPEECH:
ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў They are at home?! MRS REYNOLDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Darcy is always down for the summer. Mr Darcy is due here tomorrow. MR GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your master much at Pemberley? MRS REYNOLDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as much as I would wish, sir, or he -- for he dearly loves it here. Relaxed again Elizabeth wanders off as the Gardiners talk to Mrs Reynolds. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he should marry, you might see more of him. MRS REYNOLDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes madam, but I do not know when that will be. I do not know a lady who is good enough for him. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Г‚ВЂВў MRS REYNOLDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've known Mr Darcy since he was a boy. He was always a kind and generous person even then. Not everyone can see it, because he does not make a meal of it like a lot of young men nowadays. But he is the most sweet-tempered and kind- hearted man I have ever known. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Gardiners look at more paintings, Elizabeth drifts out through the open doors and onto a terrace. In the bright sunlight the view of the gardens and valley beyond is exquisite. Outside the music we heard before is louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth wanders aimlessly across the terrace, being unconsciously drawn by the music. Suddenly Elizabeth recognizes the tune (perhaps it is one she has played earlier - but this time it is played exquisitely). She follows the music round a corner, intrigued as she gets ГўВЂВў closer and closer to its source. She finally reali is outside the room where the music is being played.
She steals herself a moment, but her curiosity gets the better of her and she discretely peeps in. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window she sees Georgina Darcy, a beautiful fifteen year old playing the piano with great passion and fluency. She is moved by the music and listens. After sometime, then someone steps into her view but is mostly hidden by shadows in the room. He is directly behind Georgina and gently puts his hands over her eyes. Georgina stops playing and laughs uproariougly. She stands and kisses the figure, the sunlight hits his face. It is Darcy. Georgina and Darcy kiss. Elizabeth is stunned to see him there. Darcy glances up and sees Elizabeth watching him. For a moment they both stare at each other frozen with surprise. Georgina starts in fright at the figure, Elizabeth turns and runs. Darcy comes out after her. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bennet! Elizabeth stops, appallingly embarrassed. Darcy catches up with her. They both blush, deeply. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were in London. DARCY (STUPIDLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I'm not. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Another ghastly silence. Then they both speak at once. DARCY ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came here a day early - We wouldn't have come - DARCY ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- some business with my I'm so terribly sorry - STEWARD -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop. He gazes at her with great emotion. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm visiting Derbyshire with my uncle and aunt. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to recover) And are you having a pleasant trip? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very pleasant. Tomorrow we go to Matlock.
DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Tomorrow? (DISAPPOINTED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you staying at Larnbton? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. At the Rose and Crown. Another pause. She extends her hand. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry to intrude. They said the house was open for visitors. I had no idea... She shakes his hand and starts to walk away. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I see you to the village? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no! I'm very fond of walking. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mr Darcy. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hurries away. He gazes after her. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wood. Now she is out of sight Lizzie collapses on a log. She is utterly undone. Around her, the birds sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that night. Lizzie comes downstairs, for supper. And stops. Through a gap in the door to the restaurant she sees Mr Darcy talking to her aunt and uncle. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - I shall send my carriage at noon After a moment Darcy leaves and Elizabeth approaches the table. 0 MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie, I've just met Mr Darcy! Why didn't you tell us you had seen him? He's asked us to dine with him tomorrow - He was very civil, was he not? Г‚ВЂВў MR GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very civil.
MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Not at all like you painted him. ELIZABETH (STARES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To dine with him? MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - there is something pleasing about his mouth, when he speaks. MR GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mind delaying our journey for another day? Elizabeth shakes her head, dumbly. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He particularly wishes you to meet his sister. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A footman escorts Elizabeth and the Gardiner's through the stupendous library. From the drawing room, the sound of a piano playing.. It's the same music Elizabeth played at Rosings, but this time played very beautifully. Elizabeth is filled with trepidation; we can almost feel her heart racing. The footman opens the double doors to reveal the magnificent drawing room. Darcy is there. So is the dreaded Miss Bingley. Seeing her, Elizabeth's polite smile falters. Darcy's sister Georgiana plays the piano. She jumps up and hurries over. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister, Miss Darcy... They smile and bob. Georgiana is a friendly, sweet girl. GEORGIANA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Elizabeth, my brother has told me so much about you. I feel as if we are friends already. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a beautiful instrument. GEORGIANA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother gave it to me. (smiles at him) He shouldn't have.
DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Yes I should. GEORGIANA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh very well then. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's easily persuaded, is she not? They gaze at each other with affection. Miss Bingley approaches. MISS BINGLEY (SMALL SMILE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a surprise, Miss Bennet, to see you in Derbyshire. ELIZABETH (SMALL NOD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brother is well, I trust? MISS BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. He hopes to come here soon. (significant glance at GEORGIANA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pemberley has a special attraction for him. Г‚ВЂВў ELIZABETH (SWEETLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, the library is particularly splendid, is it not? A small silence. Darcy, uneasy at their conversation, approaches. MISS BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how is your family, Miss Bennet? Someone told me the militia are removed from Meryton. (SIGNIFICANT SMILE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must be a great loss for some of you Darcy comes to the rescue. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your uncle is fond of fishing, I hear. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, very. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drawing her away) Can you persuade him to borrow a rod this afternoon? (MORE)
DARCY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the lake here is very well stocked and its occupants left in peace for far ГўВЂВў too long. Elizabeth smiles, surprised and delighted. And grateful to be rescued. What does Mr Darcy mean by this? She moves away, to speak to her uncle. Miss Bingley moves closer to Darcy. MISS BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In six months I have never seen anyone so altered. How brown and coarse she has become! DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I perceive no alteration' except she is rather tanned. Hardly a miraculous consequence of travelling in the summer. MISS BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember, when we first knew her in Hertfordshire, you said "she a beauty? I would have as soon called her mother a wit!" DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have mis-heard, Caroline. Even had I thought it, I would have couched it Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with a little more finesse. Elizabeth looks across at Darcy - they smile at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darcy is driving Elizabeth and the Gardiner's back to Lampton. The rugged landscape looks even more beautiful and dramatic in the dusk light. Elizabeth sits up with Darcy who holds the reins, while Mr and Mrs Gardiner sit comfortably in the carriage. Mr Gardiner smiles broadly at two large fish that lie beside him. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is so beautiful up here. I will be sorry to leave. Darcy smiles at her. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been a most gracious host. I'm sure my aunt and uncle will talk of nothing else for days. Г‚ВЂВў DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have recently thought a great deal about how I appear and act to others.
She smiles softly at Darcy. Г‚ВЂВў ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does you credit, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party arrive back at the inn. MR GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly to Elizabeth) What a capital fellow. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much Mr Darcy. Darcy is about to take his leave when a servant brings Elizabeth a letter. SERVANT (TO LIZZIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you, madam. ELIZABETH (DELIGHTED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 107 Its from Jane. 10 ГўВЂВў she rips open the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is crying with the open letter in her hand. Darcy and Mr and Mrs Gardiner stand dumb, not quite knowing what to do. Elizabeth tries to speak but bursts into tears again. She cries for a long time. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Elizabeth. She cries on. DARCY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Elizabeth. She eventually gathers herself. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the most dreadful news. Lydia has run away - with Mr Wickham. They are gone together from Brighton to Lord knows where. She has no money, no connections, I fear she is lost forever. 0
DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў (quietly to Elizabeth) This is my fault - if only I had exposed Wickham when I should. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is my fault. I might have prevented all of it by merely being open with my sisters rather than too proud with my knowledge. Mr and Mrs Gardiner look at each other perplexed. MRS GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has anything been done to recover her? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father has gone to London. But I know very well that nothing can be done. We have not the smallest hope. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would to heaven that anything could be said or done on my part that could offer consolation to such distress. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, it think it is too late. Г‚ВЂВў MR GARDINER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am afraid we must go at once - I will join Mr Bennet and find Lydia before she ruins the family forever. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so very sorry. This is grave indeed. I will leave you. Goodbye. Darcy pauses at the door, looks back at Elizabeth and then is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gardiner's carriage racing through the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, Jane, Mary and Kitty are gathered around Mrs Bennet who has taken to her bed. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did the Foresters let her out of their sight? I always said they were unfit to have charge of her.
MARY (SMUGLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now she is ruined. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are all ruined. Who will take you now with a fallen sister? Poor Mr Bennet will now have to fight the perfidious Wickham and then be killed... ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't found him yet, Mama. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and The Collins' will turn us out before he is cold in his grave - JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not be alarmed, mama. Our uncle is helping in the search. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia must know what this will do to my nerves, such flutterings and spasms all over me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were looking directly down onto a London street. Mr Bennet stands still against the passing pedestrian traffic. He tries to address a passer by. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. They ignore him. He tries again

dialogues.speaker: MR BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I'm looking for... Mr Bennet takes out a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bennet walks timidly into the mess hall. It is smoky, drunken, noisy, boisterous and extremely threatening. Mr Bennet stops at the threshold, gulps, then the whole room turns round to look at him and a sudden silence descends. Mr Bennet is terrified. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am...(his voice breaks up - he clears his throat) I am looking for a Mr ГўВЂВў Wickham.
Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Jane are outside Mrs Bennet's room. From inside we hear a moan.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BENNET, (OFF)
dialogues.text: We are ruined. Ruined. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is this going to go on for? JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be too harsh. This is hard for all of us. They walk downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Jane walk into the drawing room. Kitty and Mary are busying themselves. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't bear not hearing anything. Г‚ВЂВў KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. It's Papa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls rush into the library. Mr Bennet slumps at his desk. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - who is to fight Wickham and make him marry Lydia, now you've come home? MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake let me be! (TO LIZZIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie, help me with my boots. Elizabeth pulls off his boots for him. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You suppose them to be still in London? MR BENNET (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where else could they be so well concealed? Г‚ВЂВў ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh father, I'm so sorry.
MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў It's been my own doing. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mustn't be too severe on yourself. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Lizzie. Let me once in my life feel how much I have been to blame. (WAN SMILE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not afraid of being overpowered by the experience. It will pass away soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. BOARDING HOUSE
dialogues.text: We're looking through a window to the stairwell of a seedy looking boarding house. An anonymas pair of mens boots appear climbing up the stairs. We move across the exterior wall of the building to find an open window through which Lydia and Wickham can be seen. Lydia and Wickham sit, snuggled close beside the fire in their room in a humble lodging house. They're eating a meal with relish. Giggling, Lydia feeds him a mouthful. A knock at the door. They freeze, like naughty children. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls have a letter. Kitty grabs it from Jane, Mary grabs it from Kitty, before she has a chance to open it Jane grabs it from Mary. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's to Daddy. It's in uncle's writing. Mr Bennet snatches the letter. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it is addressed to me... He tears it open and begins to read, squinting because he has forgotten his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: MR BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's found them. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they married? MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squinting at the letter) Just wait. I can't make out his script.
Elizabeth snatches it. Г‚ВЂВў ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to me. (she reads) KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they married? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will be, if father will settle a hundred pounds a year on her. That is Wickham's condition. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred pounds! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will agree to this, father? The letter is passed around the other girls. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I will agree. But how much your uncle has laid on this wretched man already is anybody's guess. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Father? Г‚ВЂВў MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No man in his senses would marry Lydia on so slight a temptation as a hundred a year. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, I see. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what? MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your uncle is very generous. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think it a large sum? MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wickham's a fool if he takes her for less than ten thousand pounds. I should be sorry to think so ill of him in the very - beginning of our relationship. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten thousand! Heaven forbid!
ГўВЂВў 107 INT. MR & MRS BENNET'S BEDROOM - LONGBOURN Close on Mrs Bennet's face as she springs out of bed. Pure triumphant joy. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia married! And at sixteen too! Ring the bell, Kitty! I must put on my things and tell Lady Lucas! Oh to see her face! And tell the servants they will have a bowl of punch! The other Bennet's are assembled. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should thank our uncle, Mama. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so he should help! He's much richer than us, and he hasn't got any children. ELIZABETH (ANGRILY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you talk like that? Her mother gets to her feet. Г‚ВЂВў MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A daughter, married! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all you think about? MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Mrs Wickham" - how well it sounds ELIZABETH (IN DESPERATION)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know what he's like MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now where will they live? Purvis Lodge might do. Ashworth is vacant of course, but it's too far off, I couldn't bear to have her ten miles from me - MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you take any of these houses, Mrs Bennet, let us be clear. Into one house she will never be welcome. Mrs Bennet stares at him. 9

ГўВЂВў 108 INT. HALLWAY - LONGBOURN - DAY. 108 Lydia's triumphant face. The cat that's got the cream. She comes into the house with Wickham. Her mother kisses her, effusively. Mr Bennet coldly bows. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and then we passed Sarah Sims in her carriage so I took off my glove and let my hand just rest on the window frame, so she might see the ring, and then 1 bowed and smiled like anything! Kitty shrieks with envy. Lizzie moves away; she cannot bear it. Wickham catches her eye, but she ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are taking their seats for dinner. Lydia moves to the head of the table. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, I take your place now, and you must go lower, for I am the married woman. She sits down and giggles at her sisters. The maid brings ГўВЂВў in the food. Lydia holds up her hand, to display h to the maid. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must all go to Brighton, for that is the place to get husbands! I hope you have half my good luck. ELIZABETH (FURIOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia! CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wickham looking uncomfortable. He's talking to the stony- faced Mr Bennet. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
