dialogues.text: I've been enlisted in a regiment in the north of England, sir. l f G MR BENNET (NODS COLDLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad to hear of it. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near Newcastle. We shall travel there next week.
KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Can I come and stay with you? MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is out. of the question. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia, rattling on to Lizzie. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Monday morning came and I was in such a fuss - ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear - LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - there was my aunt, preaching and talking away just as if she was reading a sermon, she was horrid unpleasant - ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you understand why? LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - but I didn't hear a word because I was thinking of my dear Wickham. I longed to ГўВЂВў know whether he would be married in his blue coat... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turning to Wickham. MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The north of England, I believe, boasts some spectacular scenery... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia burbling on, to a stony-faced Lizzie. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and then my uncle was called away from the church on business and I thought - who is to be our best man if he doesn't come back? Lucky he did come back or I would have had to ask Mr Darcy - ELIZABETH (STARES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy? LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (claps her hand to her mouth) I forgot! I shouldn't have said a word!
Г‚ВЂВў ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy was at your wedding? LYDIA (WHISPERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was the one that discovered us! He knew where to find Wickham, you see. (HISSES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't tell anyone! He told me not to tell! Lizzie stares at her. Darcy at her wedding? Lydia turns away, to talk to the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia, croquet mallet in hand, drags her new husband across the lawn. Kitty follows. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Wickham! You've got to play. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, come on! Wickham looks slightly abashed - a trapped man. What has he let himself in for? Lizzie comes into the garden, looking for her younger sister. Wickham detaches himself and comes over to her. A rueful smile. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope we can be even better friends, now we're brother and sister. An attempt at a twinkling smile, but Elizabeth is now immune to his charm. She nods, briefly. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you visited Pemberley. My dear old home. ELIZABETH (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met Mr Darcy's sister. WICKHAM (A BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you like her? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very much. (looks at him) We found a great deal to talk about.
A beat. Wickham looks deeply uneasy. He bows and leaves. Lizzie watches him pick up a mallet and take his turn. She can't bear it; she hurries up to Lydia and draws her aside. ELIZABETH (LOW VOICE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why was Mr Darcy there? LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not supposed to tell. Lizzie abandons her pride. She takes Lydia's hand. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Lydia! LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he paid for it. ELIZABETH (STARES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? LYDIA (CARELESSLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wedding, Wickham's commission. Everything. Г‚ВЂВў ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything? KITTY (CALLS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia! It's your turn! Lydia moves to go. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People kept saying Wickham owed them money, it was so tedious. So Darcy settled his debts but I don't really like him, do you? Lizzie pulls her back. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why did he do it? LYDIA (SHRUGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, do I? Anyway you're not to tell because it's supposed to be our uncle who paid, and he wouldn't have ГўВЂВў minded paying, either, because I'm his favorite.
ГўВЂВў She leaves. Giggles and shrieks from the croquet l Elizabeth looks blank with shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Darcy's grimly determined face. Drawing back, we see that he is walking down a street in Mayfair. He arrives at a house, pauses, and rings the bell. The door is opened. BUTLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have some business with Mr Bingley. Darcy goes inside and the door shuts. The camera cranes slowly upstairs until we can see through the first floor window and into the drawing room. Mr Darcy enters and bows to Mr Bingley. He starts to talk in earnest. Bingley looks stunned by what Darcy is relaying to him. We witness the dumbshow of Darcy confessing that he has wronged Jane Bennet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia and Wickham are leaving. Mr Bennet stands at a distance. Mrs Bennet sobs as Lydia climbs onto the carriage. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write to me often, my dear'. Wickham takes his leave of Elizabeth. WICKHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please relay my affections to the Darcy's on your next acquaintance. I am sure he will be pleased to hear things have worked out so well. He joins Lydia. LYDIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through the window) Married women never have much time for writing. My sisters may write to me! They'll have nothing else to do. The Mrs Bennet and the girls watch as the carriage drives away. 0
MRS BENNET Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh there is nothing so bad as parting with ones children! One seems so forlorn without them. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is the consequence of marrying a daughter. It must make you better satisfied that your other four are single.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Jane are out shopping with their mother and sisters. Their housekeeper, Mrs Hill, comes out of the butchers shop. MRS HILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear the news, madam? Mr Bingley is returning to Netherfield. A stunned silence. Lizzie glances at Jane. She blushes. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bingley? Mrs Hill indicates a woman in the butcher's shop. MRS HILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Nichols is ordering a haunch Of pork, for she expects him tomorrow. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow? (RECOVERING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I care about it. Mr Bingley is nothing to us and I'm sure I never want to see him again. (MOVES AWAY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we shall not mention a word about it. (comes back to Mrs Hill) Is it quite certain he is coming? MRS HILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, madam. I believe he is alone; his sister remains in town. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh! Come along, girls. Their mother goes into the draper's shop. Jane pauses at the threshold. 0
JANE Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Lizzie. I'm just glad that he comes alone, because then we shall see less of him. (BLUSHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I'm afraid of myself, but I dread other people's remarks. A brave smile. Lizzie, of course, is not convinced in the slightest. They go into the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bingley rides towards Longbourn, a look of slight trepidation in his eyes. Darcy now comes into view riding along side him. They cross the moat bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is practising her scales. Jane and Elizabeth are sitting at their work, with their mother. Kitty rushes in. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is here! He is here, he's at the door! Г‚ВЂВў MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my goodness! Everybody act naturally. Jane completely freezes. Everybody else goes into a fluster.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whatever you do, do not appear overbearing. Kitty looks out through a window. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. There's someone with him. Mr whats his name. The pompous one from before. Elizabeth looks through the window at Darcy, her heart leaps to her mouth. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy indeed! The very insolence of 0 0 it. What does he think of coming here? Elizabeth returns to her seat and sits down, heavily. Mrs Bennet hurries over to Jane and pinches her cheeks. Г‚ВЂВў JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama!
MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў (to Mary - who is still PLAYING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that and sit down! Find yourself some work! Oh Lord. They sit there, frozen, pretending to sew. The drawing room door opens and Mrs Hill shows in the two men. They bow. Bingley smiles warmly at Jane, who blushes. Elizabeth glances at Darcy. His face is strained. Mrs Bennet is all smiles for Bingley. She ignores Darcy.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How very glad we are to see you, Mr Bingley! There are a great many changes since you went away. Miss Lucas is married and settled. And one of my own daughters too, you will have seen it in the papers though it was not put in as it ought to have been. Very short, nothing about her family. BINGLEY (SMILES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did hear of it, and offer my congratulations. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - but it's very hard to have my Lydia taken away from me. Mr Wickham has been transferred to Newcastle, where ever that is. Thank heaven he has some friends. Mrs Bennet shoots a frosty glance at Mr Darcy. This is more than Elizabeth can bare. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you hope to stay long in the country, Mr Bingley? BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a few weeks. For the shooting. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you have killed all your own birds, Mr Bingley, I beg you will come here and shoot as many as you please. MR BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you - MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Mr Bennet will be vastly happy to oblige you, and will save all the best of ГўВЂВў the covies for you.
MR BINGLEY Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you well, Mr Darcy? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite well, thank you. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I hope the weather stays fine, for your sport. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I return to town tomorrow. ELIZABETH (A PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So soon? MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Jane looks well, does she not? Mr-Bingley stands up abruptly. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does indeed. Well, I must be going, I suppose. Darcy - Darcy cannot quite believe it. He gives Bingley a harsh stare, Bingley has not completed his task.

dialogues.speaker: BINGLEY
dialogues.text: It was very pleasant to see you all again. Elizabeth, Miss Jane.. Bingley can almost not bear to look Jane in the eye as he acknowledges them all very briefly and bolts for the door. Mrs Bennet fusses around him. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must come again. For when you were in town last winter you promised to take a family dinner with us. I have not forgot you see. At least three courses. Bingley and Darcy take their leave, leaving the Bennets sitting in silence all looking at once another. Kitty is fit to burst out laughing, Elizabeth and Jane horrified by the awkward visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Bingley is pacing backwards and forwards in despai muttering to himself. Darcy looks at him in extreme frustration.
BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh damn, damn, buggery, damn. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you thinking of? It's as if Bingley has not heard. He keeps pacing up and down. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn and blast, oh buggery, damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls are now spread around the room. Jane in. despair. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm glad that's over. We can now meet as indifferent acquaintances. ELIZABETH (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes? Jane, take care. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot think me so weak as to be in Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: danger now. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you are in great danger of making him as much in love with you as ever. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, though, that he came with Mr Darcy. ELIZABETH (BLURTS OUT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jane, I have acted so stupidly. Had I been in love, I could not have been more blind! JANE (STARES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? The door bell rings. KITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the window) It is him. He's back. He's come again. ГўВЂВў A stunned reaction. CUT TO:
Everyone has regained their decorous positions. They hear Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingley's voice at the door and he comes in very awkwardly. He smiles. His face is crimson with embarrassment. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, erm, I know this is all very embarrassing, but I would like to request the privilege of speaking to Miss Jane - They all look at him. BINGLEY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - alone. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls. Everybody to the kitchen. Immediately. Oh, Mr Bingley. It is so good to see you again so soon. She ushers everyone out, not before squeezing Jane's hand. Now Jane and Bingley are alone, facing each other with extreme embarrassment. BINGLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bennet, you have been the victim of a huge misunderstanding. Suffice to say, I have been an unmitigated and comprehensive ass. And therefore, I would like to ask you - CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Bennet, Kitty, Mary and Mr Bennet are all jostling for a position at the door in order to overhear events inside. MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssssshhh! Elizabeth is apart from her family. She cannot bear to be there. She walks down the corridor and out of the house into the garden. Through a window she sees Bingley on one knee, her eyes fill with tears as she walks away from the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Bingley looks at Jane, desperately worried. A paus     JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Yes. A hundred times - yes. Mrs Bennet and the girls throw open the double doors to the drawing room and come crashing in. Bingley and Jane beam at them. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank the Lord for that. I thought it would never happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is sat under a tree crying. 121 EXT. COUNTRYSIDE - OVER LOOKING LONGBOURN - THE SAME. Darcy looks down at Longbourn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bennet and Mrs Bennet are in bed. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sure they will do well together, Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: their tempers are much alike. They will be cheated assiduously by their servants, and be so generous with the rest, they will always exceed their income. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exceed their income? He has five thousand a year! I knew she could not be so beautiful for nothing. The camera moves through to another bedroom - where Mary is reading a book out loud to Kitty - then to yet another ROOM:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane and Elizabeth lie in bed. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has made me so happy. You know, he. was totally ignorant of my being in town last spring! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did he account for it? Г‚ВЂВў JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thought me indifferent!     ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfathomable. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt poisoned by his pernicious sister. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo! That is the most unforgiving speech you've ever made. JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Lizzie, if I could but see you so happy. If there were such another man for you! There is a noise outside. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps, if I have very good luck, I may meet with another Mr Collins in time. What is that? More noise, it sounds like a carriage, then a loud banging on the door downstairs. The girls look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bennet, Mrs Bennet and the girls lit by only candles have gathered. The door bangs again. MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's changed his mind. Timidly, Mr Bennet opens the door revealing a wide-eyed Lady Catherine de Bourgh. Everyone gasps. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Catherine! Lady Catherine does not acknowledge her, but comes in uninvited, inspecting the assembled company of aghast Bennets. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mrs Bennet) And these are your daughters, I suppose. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All but one, the youngest has been lately married your ladyship. And my eldest was only proposed to yesterday afternoon. Г‚ВЂВў LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a very small garden, madam.
MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў I am sure it is nothing compared to Rosings, but it is larger than Sir William Lucas's, I can assure you. MR BENNET (TENTATIVELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I offer you a cup of tea, perhaps? LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely not! I must speak to Miss Elizabeth alone, as a matter of complete urgency. The Bennets all look at each other", bewildered by this strange turn of events.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth leads the way into the drawing room - lights an oil lamp. Lady Catherine walks in. The door closes behind them. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can be at no loss, Miss Bennet, to understand why I am`here. ГўВЂВў Lit only by the oil lamp Lady Catherine resembles flickering ghoul. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed you are mistaken. I can not account for this honour at all. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bennet, I warn you, I am not to be trifled with. A report of a most alarming nature has reached me that you intend to be united with my nephew, Mr Darcy. Elizabeth stares at her, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CATHERINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know this to be a scandalous falsehood, though not wishing to injure him by supposing it possible, I instantly set off to make my sentiments known. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you believed it impossible, I wonder you took the trouble of coming so far. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hear it contradicted, Miss Bennet.
ELIZABETH (COOLLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your coming here will be rather a confirmation, surely, if indeed such a report exists. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If? Do you then pretend to be ignorant of it? Has it not been industriously circulated by yourself? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have never heard of it. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And can you declare there is no foundation for it? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your ladyship. You may ask the questions, which I may not choose to answer. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not to be borne. Has my nephew made you an offer of marriage? IS ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Ladyship declared it to be impossible. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me be understood. Mr Darcy is engaged to my daughter. Now what have you to say? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only this - if that is the case you can have no reason to suppose he will make an offer to me. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh obstinate girl! This union has been planned since their infancy. Do you think it can be prevented by a young woman of inferior birth, of no importance in the world and wholly unallied to his family? Whose own sister's elopement resulted in the scandalously patched-up marriage, only achieved at the expense of your uncle? Heaven and earth, are the shades of Pemberly to be thus polluted? Now tell me once and for all, are you engaged to him? Г‚ВЂВў ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not.
LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And will you promise never to enter into such an engagement? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not. And I certainly never shall. Allow me to say, the arguments which you have supported this extraordinary application have been as frivolous as the application was ill-judged. You have, insulted me in every possible method and can now have nothing further to say. I must ask you to leave immediately. Good night. Elizabeth throws open.the door, revealing the family outside. LADY CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have never been thus treated in my entire life. Lady Catherine storms past the family and out into the night. Elizabeth is standing shaking with the excitement of having stood so firmly up for herself. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie, what on earth is going on? Г‚ВЂВў ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a small misunderstanding. She walks past them to bed. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For once in your life. Just leave me alone. Everyone looks aghast at Elizabeth's reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is fast asleep. Elizabeth unable to sleep. She quietly climbs out of bed and creeps out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth sits alone downstairs, thinking. Outside we see dawn is breaking.
Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth creeps out into the garden and wanders around through the early morning mist, as the sun starts to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth walks out into the open countryside. The mists are starting to evaporate. From out of the mist in the distance a figure emerges. Her heart misses a beat. She is alone, vulnerable. Then she sees it is Darcy. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy! DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing out here so early? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could not sleep. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither. I have been up.most of the night. Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth hardly knows how to react at this unexpected meeting. Rather politely she thanks Mr Darcy. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy, I must thank you for your unexampled generosity to both my sisters. I know what kindnesses you have done for poor Lydia and suspect your hand in the happy resolution for Jane also. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am alarmed that you know of what I have been so in earnest to keep silent. But you must know that your happiness was one of my prime inducements. Elizabeth looks at Darcy.

dialogues.speaker: DARCY
dialogues.text: I know you are too generous to trifle with me. I believe you spoke with my Aunt last night, and it has taught me to hope as I had scarcely allowed myself before. If your feelings are still what they were last April, tell me so at once. My affections and wishes are unchanged, but Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: one word from you will silence me forever.
Elizabeth is silent. 0 DARCY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If, however, your feelings have changed... Elizabeth gazes at him. DARCY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have to tell you, you have bewitched me body and soul and I love and love and love you. And never wish to be parted from you from this day on. Elizabeth looks at him. She does not say a word. Darcy is staring at her for a reply. A tear rolls down Elizabeth's cheek. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am very happy to inform you that not only have my sentiments changed there are no other words which could give me greater pleasure. Darcy stares at her. They both start to cry. Darcy very, very slowly and gently touches her face. She closes her eyes. They kiss. She touches his face with her hand, the kiss becomes passionate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is in an uproar. Bingley, Jane, Mary, Kitty, Mr and Mrs Bennet are all gathered, fretting terribly about Elizabeth's whereabouts. Through a window we see Elizabeth lead Darcy along the duck board plank across the moat. Elizabeth enters the house, everybody starts. MRS BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie, where have you been. We thought something had happened to you. Darcy follows Elizabeth in.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy! What on earth are you doing here? Elizabeth takes Mr Darcy's hand. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Darcy has come to speak with Papa. Everyone is stunned. 0 CUT TO

ГўВЂВў 131 INT. HALLWAY/LIBRARY - LONGBOURN - DAY. 131 Elizabeth paces outside the door of the library, waiting. After a while Darcy emerges, he gives Elizabeth the briefest of smiles and leaves the door open. Elizabeth walks in. Her father is in a state of shock. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizzie, are you out of your senses? I thought you hated the man. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Papa. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is rich, to be sure, and you will have more fine carriages than Jane. But will that make you happy? ELIZABETH (UNCOMFORTABLE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you no other objection than your belief in my indifference? MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None at all. We all know him to be a proud, unpleasant sort of fellow, but this would be nothing if you really liked him. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tears in her eyes) I do like him! (WITH PASSION)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love him! He's not proud. It's I who's been prejudiced, who didn't realize ... You don't know him, Papa...if I told you what he's really like. What he's done. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What has he done? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darcy, in an agony, paces up and down the lawn. He looks at the library window.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў 133 INT. LIBRARY - LONGBOURN - DAY. 133 Mr Bennet stares at his daughter.
MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord. I must pay him back. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) No, you mustn't tell anyone! He wouldn't want it. (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We misjudged him, me more than anyone. In every way,not just in this matter. I've been so blind. He's been so blind! About Jane, about so many things. Then so have I... (BREATHLESS PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, he and I are so similiar...we're both so stubborn... (SHAKY LAUGH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Papa... Mr Bennet gazes at his daughter-. He still can't quite take it in. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do love him, don't you? Elizabeth nods. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВў Very much. He looks at her earnestly, searching her face. He loves his daughter very deeply. What he sees leaves him in no doubt. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot believe that anyone can deserve you, but it seems I am over-ruled. So I heartily give my consent. Elizabeth jumps up and puts her arms around him. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could not have parted with you, my Lizzie, to any one less worthy. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh thank you! She starts to rush out. MR BENNET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out after her) And if any young men come for Mary or Kitty, send them in, for I am quite at ГўВЂВў leisure.

ГўВЂВў 134 EXT. PEMBERLY - NIGHT. 134 We move through a vast wedding party, following Elizabeth and Darcy. We meet all our characters. Lydia and Wickham are missing. Let everyone have an end. Darcy and Elizabeth kiss, then Darcy pulls Elizabeth off into the shadows. We see them disappear into the park. Coming close, we see them in the moonlight. It's Darcy and Elizabeth. Deer turn to gaze at them. The music fades as they walk further from the house, up the hill, past the outcrops of rocks. An owl hoots. Darcy turns to Elizabeth and smiles. DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow me, Mrs Darcy. He puts out his hand. She takes it. He helps her up the rocks. When they get to the top they sit there, side by side, and gaze at the distant lights of Pemberley. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did it begin? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot fix the hour, or the spot, or Г‚ВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the look. It was too long ago and I was in the middle before I knew it had begun. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now be sincere, did you admire me for my impertinenc? DARCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the liveliness of your mind, I did. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may as well call it impertinence, though make a virtue of it by all means. My good qualities are under your protection, and you are to exaggerate - them as much as possible. And, in return, it belongs to me to find occasions for teasing and quarrelling with you as often as maybe... and I shall begin directly... We draw back-their figures diminish, smaller and smaller under the immense, star-spangled sky. . .Fainter and fainter, the sound of music and laughter...
